doc_title: Conventional versus additive manufacturing in the structural performance of dense alumina-zirconia ceramics: 20 years of research, challenges and future perspectives
doc_abstract: © 2022 The Society of Manufacturing EngineersThe current need to develop Additive Manufacturing (AM) processes capable of producing defect-free, fully-dense functional ceramics could benefit from the knowledge consolidated throughout the years in conventional processing. This review provides an up-to-date status of AM fabrication of dense alumina, zirconia and their composites, in comparison with reference values published during 20 years of research on powder pressing and colloidal-based technologies. A systematic literature search on conventional methods and AM selected 1706 papers and, after screening, 344 papers included 1313 different experiments reporting relative density and mechanical properties (flexural strength, elastic modulus, hardness and fracture toughness) of the final ceramics. The associations between experimental processing conditions, densification and, subsequently, mechanical performance were evaluated in powder- and suspension-based technologies. The research evolution in the fabrication of these ceramics over the last two decades is also summarized, highlighting the most used AM technologies for each material and the place of functional ceramics in recent and future market perspectives. Furthermore, future insights in the fabrication of functional ceramics are identified, to guide researchers and commercial players in drawing scientific and industrial novelties for developing new business strategies, key decision-making and road mapping to make the AM market of functional ceramics a reality.

distribution of several materials properties: relative density (RD), flexural strength (FS), fracture toughness (KIc), hardness (H), Young’s modulus (E) and alumina and zirconia grain size (Gr) as a microstructural feature, as a function of the ZrO2 (vol%) content in the mixture. Due to the small number of experiments with mixtures, the classes 0, ]0,20], ]20,80[, [80,100[ and 100 ZrO2 vol% are considered, where ZrO2 (vol%) equal to 0 % corresponds to Al2O3 (vol%) equal to 100 %. The number of experiments in each boxplot is reported in the bottom lines. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Boxplots displaying the distribution of particle size of raw materials (PS), sintering temperature (ST) and holding time (t), as a function of the ZrO2 (vol%) content in the mixture, for the database entries with RD ≥ 98% and distinguishing CPP and CCT processes. Same description as in Fig. 1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 – Boxplots displaying the distribution of several materials properties: flexural strength (FS, 3pt), Young’s modulus (E), hardness (H), fracture toughness (KIc), and alumina and zirconia grain size (Gr) as a microstructural feature, as a function of the ZrO2 (vol%) content in the mixture, for the database entries with RD ≥ 98 %. Due to the small number of experiments with mixtures, the classes 0, ]0,20], ]20,80[, [80,100[ and 100 ZrO2 vol% are considered, where ZrO2 (vol%) equal to 0 % corresponds to Al2O3 (vol%) equal to 100 %. The number of experiments in each boxplot is reported in the bottom lines. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 – Distribution plot showing the percentage of AM database entries (total of 357 entries) reporting relative density (RD), flexural strength (FS), hardness (H) and fracture toughness (KIc) distinguishing suspension (240) and powder-based (117) technologies. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 – Boxplots displaying the distribution of the relative density (RD, %) regarding alumina (Al2O3), zirconia (ZrO2) and alumina-zirconia entries, comparing AM technologies powder-based (AM powder) with conventional powder pressing (CPP) and AM technologies suspensions-based (AM suspension) with conventional colloidal techniques (CCT). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 – Boxplots displaying the distribution of particle size of (PS) alumina (Al) and Zirconia (Zr) raw powders, for all compositions: alumina (0% ZrO2), zirconia (100% ZrO2) and their composites, comparing AM technologies powder-based (AM-powder) with conventional powder pressing (CPP) and AM technologies suspensions-based (AM-suspension) with conventional colloidal techniques (CCT). For the sake of clear visualization, the y-axis was set to the interval [0,5] μm. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 – Boxplots displaying the flexural strength (FS, 3pt) for alumina (0% ZrO2), Zirconia (100 % ZrO2) and their composites, comparing powder-based AM technologies (AM-powder) with conventional powder pressing (CPP) and suspension-based AM technologies (AM-suspension) with conventional colloidal techniques (CCT). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 – Boxplots displaying the distribution of the relative density (RD, %) for the AM database entries regarding alumina (Al2O3), zirconia (ZrO2) and alumina-zirconia ceramics (Al2O3+ ZrO2) per AM categories (excluding one SL database entry). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 – Number of published papers and corresponding database entries per year, distinguishing the counts for AM, CPP and CCT production processes. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 – Percentage of AM database entries with the participation of, at least, one institution per country. Overall, institutions from 30 countries were involved in the publication of papers leading to, at least, one AM database entry. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 – Sunburst showing the distribution of database entries per AM category (the inner circle) and technology (the outer circle) distinguishing the dense ceramics of pure Al2O3 (172 entries), pure ZrO2 (136 entries) and Al2O3 + ZrO2 mixtures (50 entries). The technologies with very few entries were omitted for the sake of overall visualization. Same colour scheme as in Fig. 8 and Table 7. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 – Sunburst showing the distribution of the AM market by category (inner circle: Materials, Services and Hardware) and by segment (outer circle). Source data: Additive Manufacturing Landscape 2020 (AMFG, Fig. 12 Fig. 13 – (a) Total market forecast for the key ceramic AM segments: materials, parts, services and hardware [422]. (b) Future AM revenues by ceramic materials: alumina, zirconia, other technical (biomedical, silica-based – not sand, silica-based – oxide and nitride) and traditional (sand, cement, clay and glass) [423]. The number of publications, after each step of the search procedure, is also shown. The table presents the mean, standard deviation (s.d.) and the number of entries (n) for the measured variables calculated over each technology, category and material composition (ZrO2 (vol%), where zirconia volume equal to zero represents 100 vol% alumina ceramics). The current need to develop Additive Manufacturing (AM) processes capable of producing defect-free, fully-dense functional ceramics could benefit from the knowledge consolidated throughout the years in conventional processing. This review provides an up-to-date status of AM fabrication of dense alumina, zirconia and their composites, in comparison with reference values published during 20 years of research on powder pressing and colloidal-based technologies. A systematic literature search on conventional methods and AM selected 1706 papers and, after screening, 344 papers included 1313 different experiments reporting relative density and mechanical properties (flexural strength, elastic modulus, hardness and fracture toughness) of the final ceramics. The associations between experimental processing conditions, densification and, subsequently, mechanical performance were evaluated in powder- and suspension-based technologies. The research evolution in the fabrication of these ceramics over the last two decades is also summarized, highlighting the most used AM technologies for each material and the place of functional ceramics in recent and future market perspectives. Furthermore, future insights in the fabrication of functional ceramics are identified, to guide researchers and commercial players in drawing scientific and industrial novelties for developing new business strategies, key decision-making and road mapping to make the AM market of functional ceramics a reality. Powder Pressing Colloidal Additive Manufacturing Slip casting Gel casting Mechanical properties 1 Introduction Technical ceramics, also known as advanced ceramics, exhibit high performance in distinct applications thanks to their composition and structural properties because of their strictly controlled processing conditions [1]. Among others, alumina (Al2O3) [2,3] zirconia [4] (ZrO2, mainly yttria-stabilized tetragonal zirconia polycrystal, Y-TZP), and their composites, namely zirconia toughened alumina (ZTA) and alumina toughened zirconia (ATZ) [5], are common technical ceramics used in several industrial applications. The excellent thermal, mechanical, electrical and optical properties make them suitable materials to be applied in several domains including aeronautics, energy and refractories industry (such as burners, filters, engine blades, as support for electrical microdevices and chips, capacitors, varistors and semiconductors), as well as in biomaterials field, e.g. prostheses or dentistry materials [1–5]. These functionalities require parts with complex architectures and tight limits in dimensions and properties, thus demanding a high-quality control by the manufacturing companies. Nowadays, at the industrial level, alumina- and zirconia-based ceramics for technical applications are produced by conventional technologies, including powder pressing or colloidal-based ones [3]. Powder pressing and/or distinct sintering processes, such as Hot Isostatic Pressing (HIP), result in reduced or negligible porosities, desired to achieve advanced performance. However, complex shapes are only possible through the use of time-consuming machining with inherent significant increases in wastes and production costs, resultant to the use of diamond cutting and grinding tools (estimated to account for more than 70 % of the total manufacturing costs) [6,7]. Overcoming these disadvantages, colloidal-based techniques, also known as near-net-shape technologies, have made possible the production of ceramic parts close to the final shape, requiring minimal (or even non-existent) machining and finishing processes [8]. While highly advantageous for complex shapes, disadvantages related to the mould production and casting difficulties can be appointed to these techniques, more pronounced for small geometries and parts. According to the size and geometry of the piece, the drying process in these technologies could also be a critical step, where several microcracks can be formed, weakening the properties of the final material. Additive manufacturing (AM) technologies appear as promising alternatives to fabricate ceramic components with complex design and high controlled shape, geometry and size [9]. The ability to produce prototypes, customized parts and low-volume productions without the use of costly mould tooling are strong advantages for the use of AM in the ceramic industry. In the last years, AM of polymeric and metallic materials experienced a great development with several companies investing in these technologies to complement and/or replace conventional processes [10,11], and yet the scenario is different for ceramics. Several obstacles related to ceramics’ specificities, namely processing conditions (including the need for thermal treatment to achieve desired structural properties, high melting points, brittle nature and low ductility), could explain the high difficulties to elevate AM of ceramics to the same progress level as AM of polymers and metals. There is a clear need to develop further materials and reliable technologies for functional ceramics, reflected in the growing interest of research and industrial communities to design AM processes capable of producing defect-free and fully dense ceramic components. In the literature, this is supported by several published review manuscripts related to AM of ceramics, with high incidence in the last 3 years [12–15]. In 2014, Deckers et al. [12] provided a survey of AM methods to shape ceramic parts, focusing on the advantages and disadvantages of the single-step (direct) and multi-step (indirect) AM processes. After that, other general reviews related to AM of ceramics have been published mainly focused on the subject status, pairing the most appropriated methods for certain materials and applications, and summarizing the main associated challenges [10,13–16]. On the other hand, review papers more dedicated to the state of a specific AM technology for ceramic materials such as Inkjet Printing [17], Selective Laser Sintering [18,19], Laser Engineering Net-Shaped (LENS) [20] and Robocasting [21] have also been published, including specific requirements, achievements, potential and future developments of these particular technologies for ceramics. The literature also presents review papers focused on certain ceramic applications where AM already holds relevant advancements, e.g. AM of bioceramics for biomedical applications [22–25]. Two review papers published in 2020, concerning the state-of-the-art of AM of zirconia ceramics for dental applications, emphasize the importance of AM in the production of this kind of ceramics [23,24]. Zhang et al. 2020 [24] wrap up the main technologies used for the production of zirconia ceramics, the difficulties in preparing raw materials and the deficiencies and limitations in the existing AM processes. The authors state that zirconia ceramic AM processes are not very mature, and many challenges still need to be addressed mainly concerning the quality of raw materials, process control and the development of ceramic printers. Additionally, modelling and simulation were also referred to as strong tools (that need further development and implementation) to support the selection of materials and processing parameters. As an instance of that, Baltazar et al. 2021 [26] recently evaluated the influence of the in-fill orientation of filaments of alumina ceramics printed by robocasting, through the results of laboratory experiments, modelling and simulation. Finally, Lakhdar et al. 2021 [27] provide a recent and extensive revision regarding the AM progress in advanced ceramic materials, with a focus on the evaluation of the capabilities of each AM technology applied to several functional ceramics, emphasizing the reported results in terms of density, surface finish and mechanical properties. Opportunities, issues, advantages and limitations arising in the ceramics production within each technology, were also discussed. The current literature sustains that AM is becoming a feasible way to produce ceramic complex geometries and shapes, being well-established for porous ceramic parts fabrication at competitive costs. However, a lack of structural quality control is noticed when high-density ceramics are targeted, associated with several defects derived from the conditions of the printing process, nature of feedstock material and post-processes, namely particle size and size distribution of raw powders, solids loading in suspensions (when applicable), amount of organic additives, de-binding procedure, sintering temperature, among others. These factors have also been identified as key parameters in conventional ceramic manufacturing. The knowledge acquired throughout the years in the conventional AM processing of ceramic materials thus can be a strong background from which ceramic AM could absorb, benefit and evolve. Franks et al. [8] defended this idea, highlighting the relevance of the research efforts made in colloidal processing of ceramics for the advanced manufacturing of functional ceramics. The authors claim that the historical development and background knowledge in traditional colloidal shaping techniques, particle surfaces interactions in colloidal media and control of rheological properties of suspensions could be used as strong assistance for AM of ceramics. Therefore, to produce high-density ceramics for functional applications via AM, the interdependencies between the properties of the printed parts and the production settings need to be well understood. The characterization of the current status of AM technologies in the production of dense ceramics (and its comparison to that of conventional technologies) is simultaneously a challenge and a need. The goal of this paper is then to add up the current knowledge on production technologies with quantitative information to support an overview of 20 years of activity and to identify future trends and needs of research. Furthermore, this paper also aims to provide reference values for comparison in future experiments, based on literature related to the production of alumina- and zirconia-based dense ceramics. An exhaustive literature screening on conventional methods (dry pressing and colloidal) and AM processing identified 1706 research papers, from which 344 papers included quantitative information concerning, at least, one experiment. In total, 1313 experiments were identified and, for each experiment, the experimental conditions and corresponding measured properties (relative density and mechanical properties) were registered. This paper presents a detailed description of the screening process in Section 2, including the reference to the automatic search terms, the layout of the manual screening procedure, the description of the collected variables and overall counts. Section 3 provides an overview of the reported structural and mechanical properties for alumina, zirconia and alumina/zirconia composites produced by all processes. Section 4 presents the interdependencies between manufacturing techniques and mechanical performance in alumina- and zirconia-based ceramics, including an overview of the Conventional Powder Pressing (CPP), Conventional Colloidal Techniques (CCT) and AM processes together with a discussion of their advantages and disadvantages. Furthermore, the results of the systematic review (on the last 20 years of research in this field) are disaggregated to allow the comparison between different production processes, processing conditions and compositions (alumina, zirconia and mixtures of both). Section 5 presents the challenges and future perspectives in this research field, whereas Section 6 is devoted to conclusions and summarizes the main results and future perspectives in AM of technical ceramics. 2 Screening process and data analysis Scheme 1 presents the overall view of the stages implemented in this review. The screening process followed the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses) statement and stages (identification, screening, eligibility, and inclusion/exclusion criteria) [28]. Literature papers were screened through an automatic search on SCOPUS database, yielding 1706 initial papers. The title and the abstract of each paper was manually screened, looking for quantitative results on relative density and mechanical properties. Papers not presenting quantitative results were excluded. This process resulted in 344 relevant papers and the full texts were reviewed to identify reported laboratory experiments. For each of the 1313 identified experiments, the quantitative data was recorded in a database organized for the analysis. The following sections present the details of the screening process used in this paper. 2.1 Automatic search for publications The literature selection was conducted through an automatic search for publications in one of the most extensive abstract and citation databases of peer-reviewed literature (Scopus®, followed by a manual screening process based on the content of each publication. The search procedure was designed to return all articles and reviews published in peer-reviewed journals between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2020, written in English and including specific search terms (in the title, abstract or keywords field) addressing three dimensions: “materials”, “production processes” and “mechanical properties”. The “materials” dimension included the search terms “alumina”, “Al2O3”, “zirconia” and “ZrO2”, while “production processes” included search terms related to the target fabrication processes, namely CPP, CCT and AM. Finally, the dimension “mechanical properties” considered several search terms, e.g. “Vickers hardness”, “Young modulus” and “fracture toughness”. The literature selection was conducted separately for each production process through the following general full script. TITLE-ABS-KEY ((alumina OR al2o3 OR zirconia OR zro2) AND PROCESS AND (mechanical-properties OR structural-properties OR density OR vickers-hardness OR young-modulus OR fracture-toughness OR bending OR flexural OR "coefficient of thermal expansion" OR thermal-conductivity OR weibull OR "elastic modulus" OR "modulus of elasticity")) AND DOCTYPE (ar OR re) AND SRCTYPE (j) AND LANGUAGE (english) AND PUBYEAR > 1999 AND PUBYEAR < 2021 The variable PROCESS was replaced by search terms associated with each production process, according to Table 1 . The literature search was narrowed to “uniaxial pressing” and “isostatic pressing” for the CPP processes, and to “slip casting” and “gel casting” for the CCT processes. The AM literature search was organized into AM categories, with search terms including full designation and initials aiming powder- and suspension-based AM processes, namely Binder Jetting (BJ), Powder Bed Fusion (PBF), Direct Energy Deposition (DED) as mainly powder-based categories and Material Jetting (MJ), Vat Photopolymerization (VP), Material Extrusion (ME) and Sheet Lamination (SL) as mainly suspension-based categories. A general AM search (G) with the broad term “Additive Manufacturing” was also conducted as, currently, this designation is more established, although “Additive Manufacturing” and “3D printing” are still used interchangeably in many publications. Finally, the broad terms “alumina toughened zirconia” or “zirconia toughened alumina” were also considered to ensure that literature referring to ATZ or ZTA and no other manufacturing process was included. Table 1 also shows the number of publications resulting from the automatic search per production process and category. 2.2 Manual selection of publications The initial 1706 papers were manually screened in two consecutive steps: title/abstract evaluation and full-text reading. The screening process aimed at the selection of publications focusing on the analysis of dense ceramics, produced from materials solely based on alumina, zirconia and/or their mixtures, and including quantitative results on the mechanical properties of the produced ceramics. In the first step, the title/abstract content of each publication was analyzed independently by more than one reviewer (in most cases 3). A publication was excluded when all reviewers agreed that it did not attend, at least, one of the above-mentioned criteria. Most of the publications excluded by title/abstract were either i) studies not including any quantitative results on mechanical properties, ii) rheological studies of suspensions without characterization of ceramic sintered parts, iii) analyses of porous structures or core ceramics, iv) analyses focusing solely composites between alumina and/or zirconia with other materials (e.g. carbon nanotubes, titanium oxide, among others). The latter cases were considered for full-text reading whenever abstract gave evidence that composites were compared with pure ceramics (Al2O3, ZrO2, ZTA or ATZ). In the second step, all papers selected by title/abstract were accessed to exhaustive full-text reading and selected, if attending all the inclusion criteria. At the end of the screening process, 344 publications were selected to feed the database that supported the quantitative analyses presented in this paper (see Table 1 for the distribution among production process and category). Each experiment was organized as an independent entry in the database, even if reported in the same publication. All experiments were introduced by one reviewer and double-checked by another, to ensure the fidelity of the reported data. The database compiled a total of 1313 experiments/entries that were classified according to CPP, CCT and AM manufacturing processes and corresponding categories. As presented in Table 2 , the number of entries in each process sums up 455, 499 and 359, respectively for CPP, CCT and AM. For CPP, Uniaxial Pressing (UP) contributes with more entries than Cold Isostatic Pressing (CIP) and many entries are associated with processes combining UP and CIP (UP + CIP). For CCT, the number of Slip Casting (SC) entries is higher than that of Gel Casting (GC) entries, although coming from a similar number of papers. Finally, the AM categories contributing with most entries are VP, ME and PBF, and AM suspension-based processes (MJ, VP, ME and SL) have more entries than AM powder-based (BJ, PBF and DED). 2.3 Data retrieval The experimental conditions and the corresponding measured properties were registered for each identified experiment. The variables characterizing the conditions included particle size of the raw material (PS, alumina and/or zirconia, μm), sintering temperature (ST, °C), sintering holding time (t, h), ZrO2 and Al2O3 volume ratios in the mixtures (respectively ZrO2% and Al2O3%, vol%) which sums 100 % for each experiment, as well as the amounts of yttria or other stabilizing agents used in the raw zirconia powder (being the most common zirconia doped with 3 mol% yttria). For CPP techniques that used granules instead of powders, the PS recorded referred to the particle size of the raw material used for granule fabrication and not the size of the granules. For CPP and CCT processes, the additional use of specific processing conditions, e.g. Cold Isostatic Pressing (CIP), Hot Isostatic Pressing (HIP) and Microwave Sintering (MwS) was also recorded. The conditions “ST” and “time” respected HIP, when it was used instead (or after) conventional sintering step. Specific experimental conditions for each process were also included, such as the solids loading in suspensions (sloading, vol%) for CCT and some AM techniques, the pressure applied (Pressure, MPa) in UP, CIP and HIP and the nozzle diameter (ND, mm) used in AM processes. When applicable, organic additives used in the processing (Additives) were also reported for gel casting and AM technologies. The properties of the produced ceramics were registered through the mean, the standard deviation and the number of repetitions (sample size) to measure the property when the information was available and clear in the screened publication. The quantitative performance of materials included relative density (RD, %), linear shrinkage (LS, %), volume shrinkage (VS, %), grain size (Gr, μm) as well as mechanical properties, e.g. Young’s modulus (E, GPa), flexural strength (FS, MPa), fracture toughness (KIc, MPa.m1/2) and hardness (H, GPa). This work used the designation KIc for fracture toughness, instead of K1c [29], as KIc was more often referred among the entries of the final database. The quantification method was also registered for each property, e.g. for flexural strength (3-point or 4-point testing [30], respectively 3pt and 4pt) and Young’s modulus (Impulse Excitation Technique, IET, Berkovich indenter and others [31–33]). Concerning hardness, the method (Vickers and others [34,35]) and indentation load (IL, N) were registered, being Vickers the method most used to access this property (in 610 entries out of the 642 reporting H). It is worthwhile to mention that experimental conditions and properties are reported in different ways all over the literature (e.g. mixture ratio either in weight % or volume %), if not incomplete, which difficult the comparison between results from different publications. In this paper, the variable values of many entries (if reported in the screened publication) were converted into the above-mentioned physical units. E.g. ZrO2 and Al2O3 mixture ratio values reported in weight were converted to volume percentage (vol%) by using 6.05 g.cm-3 and 3.95 g.cm-3 as the theoretical density for zirconia (usually stabilized with 3 mol% of yttria) and alumina, respectively. The same theoretical density values were used to calculate the relative density (RD, %) in the sintered alumina, zirconia or alumina/zirconia materials when the data given in the paper was only bulk density (g.cm-3) measured by Archimedes’ method. 2.4 Visualization and data analysis The data were visualized through boxplots, showing the minimum/maximum values and the first/third data quartiles (in the extremities of the central box), and the median of the data (solid black line inside the central box). The width of the central box corresponds to the interquartile range (i.e. the difference between the third and the first quartile) and is a measure of dispersion based on the 50 % most central values. Outliers were identified as observations more extreme than 1.5 times the interquartile range from the first/third quartiles and represented as isolated black dots. This rule fairly identifies the points more extreme than 3 times the standard deviation from the mean, assuming a Normal distribution for the data being represented. When the sample size is ≤5, the boxplot is omitted and the median is displayed instead, to avoid misleading interpretations. Along with the text, the results are presented in terms of mean ± standard deviation (s.d.) and sample size (n), either reported in one research paper or obtained by aggregating several database entries. Dedicated visualization tools and all statistical analyses were implemented in MATLAB (version R2020a, © 1994-2020 The MathWorks, Inc.) and in IBM SPSS Statistics (version 27, © IBM Corporation). 3 Structural performance of alumina/zirconia dense ceramics: overall literature results Fig. 1 displays the distributions of the values that allow the characterization of the materials produced in the 1313 database experiments. This representation includes several properties, namely relative density (RD), flexural strength (FS), fracture toughness (KIc), hardness (H) and Young’s modulus (E), as well as the grain size (Gr) as a microstructural feature. The values are shown as a function of the volume proportion of alumina (0 % ZrO2) and zirconia (100 % ZrO2) in the mixture, regardless of the manufacturing technique and other processing conditions (e.g. amount of stabilizing agent in zirconia, raw particle size, sintering temperature and time). From a general perspective, and considering only the median values, the results are in good agreement with several literature statements for these oxide ceramics. Although showing similar median RD values, alumina (0 % ZrO2 vol%) exceeds zirconia (100% ZrO2 vol%) ceramics in terms of hardness (H) and Young’s modulus (E). There is also a higher variability in these values for alumina when compared to those for zirconia. Both properties (H and E) are highly dependent on the final microstructural features, including grain size (Gr) that also presents a high range of values for alumina ceramics in comparison to zirconia, being alumina Gr usually higher than zirconia (Fig. 1). The small grain sizes in zirconia-based ceramics are strongly associated with their importance in stabilizing the tetragonal phase, improving toughness and flexural strength [36]. Additionally, the variability observed for all mechanical properties for all materials can also be explained by the high inconsistency of processing conditions used in the different literature reports dealing with different shaping techniques, namely particle sizes of raw materials, sintering temperatures and holding time; these influences will be detailed in the next section. Zirconia is a high crack-resistant material, i.e. with high fracture toughness (KIc), presenting typically higher median FS values when compared to alumina (Fig. 1). These excellent properties are a characteristic of ZrO2 tetragonal polycrystal and are due to the transformation toughening, where crack propagation is inhibited by a stress-induced tetragonal-to-monoclinic (t → m) phase transformation accompanied by an expansion of unit cell volume of approximately 4-5 % [29,30]. In recent years, many efforts have been made to improve the toughness of ZrO2 ceramics [37] due to its growing interest in dentistry applications [38,39]. Pure zirconia presents a monoclinic (m) crystal structure thermodynamically stable at room temperature and pressure. Increasing temperature, the material transforms to tetragonal (t) structure by approximately 1170 °C and cubic (c) around 2370 °C [29]. These lattice transformations are martensitic involving a shape deformation, i.e. volume changes on cooling enough to make the pure material unsuitable for applications that require an intact solid structure [40]. So, among the three ZrO2 polymorphs, tetragonal (t-ZrO2) and cubic (c-ZrO2) zirconia have more relevant applications than monoclinic (m-ZrO2), being the tetragonal one categorized by its high fracture toughness and the cubic one by its ionic conductivity [41]. To retain tetragonal and cubic phases at room temperature, lower valence oxides (also known as stabilizing agents or dopants, such as CaO, MgO, CeO2 or Y2O3) have been explored [4,36,42–44]These tetragonal and cubic phases are characterized by the replacement of some of the Zr4+ ions in the crystal lattice of zirconia by the slightly larger ions of the dopants presenting also a fraction of oxygen sites vacant to retain charge neutrality stabilization [40]. Due to its excellent performance, yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) is the most extensively used in the literature reports [4,23,41,42,45–164]. Therefore, the features of YSZ strongly depend on structural and phase changes with respect to the Y3+ addition amounts, being corroborated by Y2O3–ZrO2 phase diagrams that tetragonal zirconia is stabilized for low contents of Y2O3, whereas excess Y2O3 additions yield tetragonal and/or cubic ZrO2 mixtures at elevated temperatures [36,41]. The amount of Y2O3 dopant required for full cubic stabilization (also known as full stabilized zirconia, FSZ) is around 8 mol%, with one oxygen vacancy created for every two yttrium ions, while partial stabilization of tetragonal zirconia (partially stabilized zirconia, PSZ) can occur at dopant concentrations around 2-5 mol%, depending on the grain size [40]. Stabilized tetragonal ZrO2 polycrystal with 3 mol% Y2O3 (3Y-TZP), which could contain up to 98 % of the metastable tetragonal phase after sintering and grain sizes lower than 0.3 μm, is the most extensively commercialized powder and consequently the highest explored in zirconia-related research. This fact is corroborated by the information in the database. Out of the 404 zirconia entries, 356 report the amount of zirconia dopant and 3 mol% Y2O3 is used in 231 entries [23,42,45,46,51–63,67,70–77,79,80,83–96,98–115,118,119,121–123,126,130,131,133,142–151,153,154,156,162]. In fact, 3Y-TZP presents a unique combination of Young’s modulus, hardness, flexural strength and fracture toughness, resulting in a ceramic with outstanding mechanical strength (aka ceramic steel) able to compete with titanium alloys in certain applications [4,41]. Moreover, 22 entries consider < 3 mol% [125,127,159–162,164,165], 47 are in the ]3,5] mol% interval [48,49,63,82,93,116,117,129] and 56 entries make use of a dopant amount > 5 mol% [110,124,137] up to exactly 8 mol% (49 entries) [68,120,130,132,139,140,145,152,155,157–159]. Although, fully stabilized cubic zirconia with 8 mol% yttria (8YSZ) combines a set of good properties (e.g. high ionic conductivity, high thermal and mechanical stability) that makes it an interesting material to be used as a solid electrolyte in fuel cells (Solid Oxide Full cells, SOFC), its poorer mechanical properties, mainly fracture toughness, limit its application in in-service situations where high mechanical stresses are applied [120,132,152,158]. All the above-discussed specificities for zirconia ceramics help to explain the high variability of the literature results displayed in Fig. 1, concerning e.g. FS (3pt and 4pt) as well as KIc for zirconia (100 ZrO2 vol%), as the results are here represented regardless of the type and the amount of dopant, if used. The mechanical performance of every single material, alumina or zirconia, could be improved through the formation of composites containing both materials in proper ratios, as supported by the results displayed in Fig. 1. Two composite materials inside the ZrO2-Al2O3 system have been studied, namely, zirconia toughened alumina (ZTA) and alumina toughened zirconia (ATZ), for which fracture toughness is expected to increase in comparison with that of the pure materials, alumina or zirconia [149,166]. The combination of a hard ceramic material, such as Al2O3 with a high toughness ZrO2 matrix (ATZ, 80 ≤ ZrO2 < 100 vol%), can produce a reinforced composite with distinctive enhancement in KIc, H and E (see Fig. 1). Oppositely, the addition of zirconia as a reinforcement material in an alumina matrix (ZTA, 0 < ZrO2 ≤ 20 vol%) could result in dissimilar improvements in KIc and FS (see Fig. 1). Other composites containing zirconia proportions of 20 < ZrO2 < 80 vol% have also been analyzed in the literature, generally addressed as ZTA when alumina is in the highest amount when compared to zirconia, and ATZ in the reverse situation. As illustrated in Fig. 1, these Al2O3-ZrO2 compositions (]20,80[ ZrO2 vol%) present increased median values of H and E when compared to zirconia (100 ZrO2 vol%), while median FS is significantly increased when compared to alumina (0 ZrO2 vol%). Therefore, the amount of zirconia and alumina to be added to the composites depends on the target property. There is no optimum combination: small amounts of zirconia should be added if a maximal hardness is required while, on the contrary, a higher concentration of zirconia should be used if maximal bending strength and a high threshold for fatigue crack propagation are required [167–169]. The database reports a total of 249 entries related to ZTA experiments (0 < ZrO2 ≤ 20 vol%) obtained from 65 research papers [51,52,54,55,66,69,72,74,87,99,122,126,147–149,154,168–213], 47 entries related to ATZ experiments (80 ≤ ZrO2 < 100 vol%) obtained from 18 manuscripts [43,60,61,67,70,74,86,87,92,122,147,149,165,168,214–217] and 147 entries associated with composites in the range of 20 < ZrO2 < 80 vol%, obtained from 46 literature papers [51,53,57,60,61,67,72,74,85,87,92,104,122,126,148,149,154,165,168,169,171,192,193,196,206,212,218–236], where the most common mixture considered 72 vol% of ZrO2 (36 entries out of 147). Almost all entries reported RD in the final material characterization, as corroborated by the similarity between the number of entries reported in Fig. 1 and the total number of entries, for each composition. Two basic concepts are mentioned in the literature to attain improved mechanical properties in alumina/zirconia composites [166,212,237,238]. One is related to regulating particle size, particle morphology and location between zirconia and alumina grains in the microstructure, which induces microcracks during cooling and thus increases the material toughness [41,212]. This is highly explored in ZTA ceramics, where the stability of the tetragonal phase when alumina is mixed with zirconia does not primarily involve the use of dopants but instead is controlled by the particle size [41]. Some authors mention that in ZTA ceramics containing up to 10 vol% of zirconia, the effect of the alumina matrix is sufficient to keep zirconia grains tetragonal if zirconia is homogeneously dispersed and does not exceed the critical size of ∼0.5 μm [212]. However, since it improves essentially toughness, using only the particle-size-related concept is not enough when flexural strength is also an important property for the required application. Bending strength and fracture toughness in zirconia/alumina composites can also be enhanced by dispersing small metastable tetragonal zirconia particles that can be transformed to the monoclinic phase in front of advancing cracks, impeding crack growth when exposed to stress. Both volume expansion and shear strain, associated with the tetragonal to monoclinic transformation, result in various toughening mechanisms in these composites (including stress-induced transformation toughening, microcracking toughening, compressive surface stresses and crack deflection) [41,166,237–239]. Furthermore, resultant microstructures influence significantly the mechanical properties of the composites, being possible to observe from Fig. 1 that, in general, alumina exhibits higher grain sizes than zirconia. Alumina grain size tends to be reduced in the presence of zirconia for all alumina/zirconia ratios since it is well-known that zirconia controls grain growth of alumina [168,170,174]. Owing to their properties, ZTA ceramics are suitable for a variety of highly demanding applications including dental screws, cutting blades, electrosurgical insulators, valve seals, body armour, pump components, oxygen sensors, dies, and prosthesis components such as hip joints [240]. Regarding ATZ composites (zirconia matrix with alumina particles, i.e. [80,100[ ZrO2 vol% class), alumina provides high hardness, while tetragonal zirconia also applies a toughening impact, on account of its controlled change into the monoclinic phase. Despite the t → m phase transformation around the crack formation as the primary toughening impact, other systems can also contribute to improve this property, such as microcracking, crack deflection and bridging in a good similarity of ZTA ceramics [57,67,149,166,171]. Microcracking is favoured in ATZ due to the zirconia expansion during cooling, leaving a system of micro-cracks in the alumina network, which empowers high strength [57,67,174,237,241]. ATZ is highly used in structural ceramic applications (e.g. wear parts and cutting tools), being also progressively selected for biomedical applications (namely femoral heads), since its quality and toughness, tribological properties and biocompatibility are favouring implants’ lifetime [57,149]. Once again, stabilized tetragonal zirconia polycrystal with 3 mol% of Y2O3 (3Y-TZP) is extensively used in both ZTA and ATZ ceramic composites (~60 % of the database entries associated with mixtures), although some authors report that optimal properties are observed for zirconia doped with 1 and 2 mol% of yttria [164,167,168,198,207,212,232,235,239]. Besides the composition and features of raw materials, also processing conditions influence the densification behaviour of the ceramic material in straight connection with microstructure (grain shape, size and distribution) and inherent impact on the final structural and mechanical performance. The fundamental studies for alumina and zirconia presented in the literature deal with samples synthesized at a laboratory scale, which show different results according to process conditions, i.e. powder-based or suspension-based shaping processes that strongly influence powder packing and, thus, final part density. Additionally, several sintering conditions have been explored with a strong impact on the microstructure and ceramics densification. The situation is even worse in the case of ZTA and ATZ ceramics, where the structural and mechanical properties of these composites are strongly dependent on the zirconia/alumina particles’ homogeneity, particle size, microstructure, grain size, sintering aids/stabilizers, different fabrication routes and sintering conditions [67,149]. The following two sections present the results and main concerns found in the manufacture of dense alumina, zirconia or mixtures of both ceramics by conventional processing techniques (CPP and CCT) and AM. 4 Interdependencies between manufacturing techniques and mechanical performance in alumina/zirconia dense ceramics Regardless of the final application, ceramic components need to be shaped by a processing methodology. These methodologies can be classified into dry or wet shaping technologies, even though both started from an initial ceramic powder. The goal of the shaping process is to obtain a green ceramic powder compact that is then sintered to achieve the desired final material. Up until now, shaping processes have been developed and optimized aiming to be cost-effective, reproducible, with tight tolerances and able to produce ceramic components without any defects. Moreover, the best-suited production technology selected for a certain product depends on the required functional properties for the target application, including shape, geometry and size of the part, if bulk or hollow, porous or dense, among other factors. In the present review, three main ceramic shaping routes have been considered as the most representative in the literature to produce dense alumina and zirconia ceramics, namely (i) Conventional Powder Pressing (CPP) including uniaxial and isostatic pressing as dry-based manufacturing technologies; (ii) Conventional Colloidal Technologies (CCT) including slip casting and gel casting as wet-based methods and (iii) Additive Manufacturing (AM) enclosing powder- and suspension-based categories. To access the current R&D status of AM processes concerning the fabrication of ceramics based on alumina, zirconia or their composites (while highlighting their strengths and present weaknesses), it is mandatory to provide an overall picture of the most established shaping routes first – the conventional ones. The following section presents the results collected from the literature for conventional dry- and wet-based processing techniques. 4.1 Conventional processing techniques This section presents an overview of the conventional (more established in literature) fabrication processes in technical ceramics based on alumina, zirconia and their composites. The discussion is supported by the database information concerning the processing conditions and the resulting properties of the produced materials. 4.1.1 Conventional Powder Pressing (CPP) Powder pressing is a conventional forming technique in which dry powders are compacted (usually in metallic moulds to form simple shapes) and the resulting shape is then submitted to a sintering step (with proper conditions of heating rate and maximum temperature depending on the material). The CPP techniques are considered the easiest procedures in ceramic production and thus are widely used to produce simple geometries. In this process, powder processing settings (milling, particle size distribution, homogeneity, applied pressure), composition and sintering schedule are parameters that should be kept into consideration to produce defects-free ceramic parts [242]. The CPP process is also known as dry pressing to emphasize that the powders are in the “dry” state, although a small amount of moisture or binder addition is usually added to help the compaction of the powders (typically 1 to 5 wt%, based on powders amount). Alternatively, powders granulation before pressing is also used to improve powders’ handling, flowability, homogeneity of all constituents (binders, sintering aids, particle sizes) and, consequently, to enhance compaction and pressing performance. Several types of pressing processes can be distinguished based on how the load is applied to the powder/granules; examples of those are uniaxial pressing and isostatic pressing. Uniaxial pressing (UP) is usually the first step that involves filling the die cavity with powder, followed by load application in one direction. Cold Isostatic pressing (CIP) is usually used after UP to improve the consistency of the material, by applying uniformly the pressure in the powder compact via a liquid that surrounds the deformable mould. Both UP and CIP are often combined with a subsequent green machining process to achieve the required complex geometry. Because of that, the remarkable disadvantages of this shaping method are related to its limitation for simple shapes, as well as the wastage of valuable material, as high amounts of material must be removed to achieve the desired shape [7,124,218,243]. To ensure the proper structural properties of the final ceramic parts obtained by dry-powder pressing, additional high-tech sintering procedures, such as Hot Isostatic Pressing (HIP), Spark Plasma Sintering (SPS) and Microwave Sintering (MwS) can be used. These procedures have been highly applied in alumina, zirconia or alumina/zirconia composites [42,64,91,120,131,148,164,165,173,197,198,211,212,229,231,235,239,242,244–249]. Since sintering is a highly energy-consuming step and a huge determinant of the final ceramic properties, research has tried to find the best trade-off between sintering conditions and final properties [36]. 4.1.2 Conventional Colloidal-based techniques (CCT) The colloidal processing routes enable good particles’ packing ability, enhancing the sintering ability at lower temperatures, avoiding coarsening of the sintered microstructure and thus improving the material performance reliability [250,251]. In these processing methods, the ceramic powders are suspended in a liquid solution (usually an aqueous medium), to generate a stable and deagglomerated suspension to cast in a mould. The preparation of suspensions is the starting point of several colloidal-based processes, such as Slip Casting (SC) and Gel Casting (GC). In SC, the suspension is poured in a typical porous plaster mould, where a particle’s layer on the inner walls of the mould is formed due to their water suction capacity. This suction causes movements of ceramic particles inside the liquid medium, usually causing particles’ segregation during layer deposition. Contrarily, in GC, the suspension is cast into a non-porous mould with a subsequent formation of a tri-dimensional network promoted by a gel system, i.e. the dispersing medium is solidified via a gelation system (chemically- or thermally-induced) according to the gel former [252]. In this way, the ceramic particles are entrapped, and both the homogeneity and the quality of the suspensions are preserved in the green piece. Acrylamide-based systems have been the most explored solutions as gel formers (n=112 database entries) [95,117,126,127,130,151,177,187,188,194,213,226,236,253–265], although epoxy-based systems (n=14) [59,266–268], natural polymers such as polysaccharides (n=37 entries) [84,150,269–276] and other thickening agents, including IsobamTM (Isobutylene polymer, Kuraray, Japan) have also been considered (n=58) [265,277–288]. Find non-toxic gelling agents that could reach the same casting behaviour and final properties of the ceramic parts have been the main driving force to go for natural materials. Although GC already achieved research feasibility at the technology readiness level, its use in the ceramics industry is not highly explored. The toxic nature of most of the gel formers (acrylamide-based, epoxy-based), casting operations, drying, storing conditions and associated process costs are some parameters that could explain the difficulties in the scalability of this technique to the industry. 4.1.3 CPP vs CCT Table 3 resumes the mean and standard deviation values obtained from all the database entries regarding experimental conditions and material properties (relative density and mechanical), distinguishing CPP and CCT shaping procedures that use conventional sintering and excluding those applying HIP. Note that the CPP and CCT related entries are respectively 335 and 492 (Table 3), which supports the research trend in conventional fabrication by colloidal-based techniques with a good trade-off between shape feasibility and complexity with concurrent proper mechanical properties. The most studied materials have been pure alumina (0 ZrO2 vol%, n=293 entries) [51–53,72,74,85,87,99,122,126,148,149,154,169,172,176,182,192,193,200,202,205,206,242,244–249,253–262,265–286,288–320] and pure zirconia (100 ZrO2 vol%, 268 entries) [42,52–56,58–61,64,67,69,72–94,99,117,120,122–131,133,137,147–165,216,264,321,322] in comparison to their composites (in a total of n=393 entries for all classes) [43,51,52,54,55,57,60,67,72,74,85–87,99,147–149,154,165,168–179,188–209,211,212,214–216,218,226,229–236,239,253,271,319], with the following number of entries per material and technology group: alumina (103 CPP and 190 CCT), zirconia (134 CPP and 134 CCT) and alumina-zirconia composites (218 CPP and 175 CCT). Regarding the Al2O3-ZrO2 composites (see ]0,20]; ]20,80];]80,100] ZrO2 vol% classes in Table 3), UP, UP + CIP, and SC have been the highly explored techniques, whereas there were no results reported for the ]20,80] class produced by GC. The relative density is the property mostly reported in the literature for alumina- and zirconia-based materials produced by CPP and CCT conventional techniques, with a total of 817 entries out of 827 (approx. 99 % reporting). Concerning the mechanical performance of the sintered materials, flexural strength (3pt or 4pt), hardness and fracture toughness are the most reported properties, while Young’s modulus is only reported in just a few entries/papers. Processing conditions According to Table 3, mean RD values for zirconia ceramics obtained by CPP vary between 93.8 and 98.6 % while, for CCT, mean RD values vary between 94.9 and 97.1 %. Regarding alumina ceramics, the mean RD range is 93.6-97.8 % and 96-96.4 %, respectively for CPP and CCT procedures. These results highlight RD differences among the different processes as well as a large RD variability among the database entries. Subsequently, RD impacts the mechanical performance of the resultant materials, being both are directly related to the processing conditions, namely particle size of raw materials (PS). According to the database, zirconia PS between 0.003 and 2.25 μm have been used for CPP processing (n=151 entries), with 26 entries showing PS > 0.5 μm [61,133,142,150,186,187,190,194,214,225] while, for CCT processing, zirconia PS varied between 0.006 and 5 μm (n=269 entries), with 14 entries reporting zirconia PS ≥ 1 μm [54,91,248,259]. Regarding alumina, CCT experiments were based on PS varying between 0.044 and 7.530 μm (n=327), where most of the experiments considered PS in the [0.3,0.6] μm interval (n=213, Table 3). The mean PS and high standard deviation presented in Table 3 for alumina powders used in UP process results to the literature work from Alias et al 2019 [248], where the authors studied the influence of using different PS (namely 25.0, 45.0, 63.0 and 90.0 μm) in the final microstructure of the sintered samples. To have a more accurate comparison between the processing variables used in CPP and CCT for alumina, zirconia and their mixtures, Fig. 2 shows the distribution of PS for alumina and zirconia raw powders in the different compositions, sintering temperature (ST) and holding time (t), considering only the entries with a relative density of the final ceramics above 98 %. Concerning PS, the literature highlights that zirconia often presents values in nanometric range and alumina in micrometric size. This is clearly shown in Fig. 2 by comparing the PS Al2O3 and PS ZrO2 boxplots, for a given composition, and observing that the median PS values tend to be much smaller for ZrO2 than for Al2O3. However, the pairwise comparison between CPP and CCT boxplots, for a given ZrO2 (vol%) content, shows different patterns both in PS ZrO2 and PS Al2O3. Distributions of the PS Al2O3 values are similar in CPP and CCT, except for pure Alumina (0 ZrO2 vol%), for which the CPP distribution exhibits a higher median and a higher variability than that for CCT. Concerning PS ZrO2, the CCT medians tend to be higher than the CPP medians for the mixtures with ZrO2 > 20 %. Note that, for these mixtures, the CCT medians for PS ZrO2 and PS Al2O3 are similar, whereas the CPP medians in PS ZrO2 are lower than those in PS Al2O3. For the pure materials (alumina or zirconia), the PS ZrO2 median is fairly lower than the PS Al2O3 median for the CPP processes whereas, on the contrary, the PS ZrO2 median is slightly higher than the PS Al2O3 one for the CCT processes. Besides the PS of the raw materials, other variables related to the processing conditions, such as load pressure, maximum temperature, atmosphere and time in the sintering step can determine the RD values. Fig. 2 shows that sintering temperature and holding time are experimental parameters more dependent on the material rather than the consolidation technique, being ST generally higher for alumina, and for composites rich in alumina (1500-1600 °C) than for zirconia (1400-1550 °C). Fig. 2 also shows that the sintering time of 2 hours corresponds to the median value among all ceramic materials (alumina, zirconia, or their composites). For example, in alumina ceramics produced by CPP, only 20 % of the database entries (15 out of 76) used temperatures ≤ 1500 °C [149,169,200,242,245,298–300], being the average holding time between 2-3 h, while only 1 database entry reported 9 h [200]. In zirconia produced by CPP, out of 100 entries, 81 % used sintering temperatures ≤ 1500 °C [50,52–54,60,61,64,81,89,91,93,94,120,129,131,133,137,147,149,156–163,184,323], whereas the remaining 19 % used ST > 1500 °C [51,55,61,67,72,76,79,85,92,99], with average holding time of 2 h. The quite large variability in sintering conditions for zirconia experiments produced by CPP or even CCT could be associated with the amount and nature of stabilizing agents used in these ceramics. In fact, several manuscripts studied the optimal conditions to attain high densities [51,64,81,89,94,149,157,159,163,180,189,191,199,200,203,204,234,245,248,300,308], whereas other studies have been focused on decreasing the sintering temperature of a certain material or optimizing several parameters in the powders compaction [129,204,230,308]. As an example, Fu et al. 2014 [300] varied UP and CIP pressures load and sintering temperatures in the fabrication of alumina by CPP and analyzed the final properties. The RD was 81 % when using UP and CIP pressures load, respectively, of 50 MPa and 150 MPa, and 1500 °C as ST. Increasing UP to 100 MPa and ST into the range 1560-1580 °C (maintaining CIP pressure load at 150 MPa), the RD increased to 98 % [300]. Schaffoner et al. 2018 [308] investigated, for the first time, the use of cycling CIP to fabricate coarse-grained alumina refractories by applying either an increase in the pressure cycle or constant cycling at maximum pressure. Although the RD values were not higher than 80 % (an expected result due to the large size of the raw alumina particles), the authors concluded that cyclic pressure slightly increases apparent density, while cycling at maximum pressure decreases the average pore size. On the other hand, the authors showed that an optimized particle size distribution results in less porosity and in a decrease in pore sizes, which increased Young’s modulus. More recently, Drazin et al. 2020 [129] demonstrated the possibility to produce zirconia dense ceramics stabilized with 4 mol% yttria (4YSZ) via dry CIP at lower sintering temperatures and using particles with nanometre size. The authors showed that the use of CIP pressures higher than 500 MPa effectively removed pores larger than 100 nm and that the pressureless sintering can occur at lower temperatures (1100-1200 °C). 4YSZ samples with an RD of 94.5 % were attained for 4 mol% yttria-stabilized zirconia (4YSZ) when sintered only at 1100 °C during 2 h. By keeping the sintering temperature at 1100 °C and increasing time up to 4 h or increasing the temperature to 1200 °C and shortening time down to 0.2 h resulted in ceramics with RD around 97 % and 96 %, respectively, with grain sizes in the order of 30-34 nm [129]. Similarly, Freitas et al. 2020 [230] developed an ATZ composite from nano-scale powder mixtures using low-sintering temperatures with a 2 h holding time. The conventional powder mixture achieved densification at 1600 °C while the nano-sized powder allowed to attain full dense samples at 1400 °C. 4.1.3.1 Mechanical Properties Fig. 3 presents the boxplots for several materials properties, namely flexural strength (FS, 3pt), Young’s modulus (E), hardness (H), fracture toughness (KIc), as well as alumina and zirconia grain sizes (Gr) as a microstructural feature, as a function of the ZrO2 (vol%) content in the mixture, considering also the database entries with relative density above 98 %. Although it was expected that CCT techniques resulted in enhanced packing density and, consequently, in better mechanical properties, when compared to CPP for the same ceramic material, this is not clear for any of the properties reported in Fig. 3. Instead, CPP technologies seem to be those achieving better properties, although showing high variability, in particular for FS. According to Fig. 3, zirconia database entries (100 ZrO2 vol%) with RD ≥ 98 % present median FS values around 750 and 1000 MPa (3pt for CPP and CCT), Young modulus around 200 and 220 GPa and median KIc around 5 and 10 MPa.m1/2, respectively for CPP and CCT processes. Hardness values are very similar for both processes with median values around 13 GPa. Considering alumina database entries (0 ZrO2 vol%) with RD ≥ 98 %, median values of FS are ≈ 500 MPa and 300 MPa, Young’s modulus ≈ 380 GPa and 350 GPa and hardness ≈ 18 and 16 GPa, when CPP and CCT have been used, respectively. Furthermore, for alumina, KIc median values exhibit a small difference between processes, being in the 4-5 MPa.m1/2 range. Regardless of the process, compared to pure alumina, FS and KIc are the mechanical properties that highly benefit from the addition of zirconia (]0,20[ and ]20, 80] ZrO2 vol% composition classes), while Young’s modulus (E) and hardness (H) improve when alumina is added to pure zirconia. These statements are also in good agreement with the results presented in Fig. 1. In fact, CPP technologies have progressed over time by using homogeneous powder mixtures in granule shape before pressing [51,52], usually attained by granulation technologies that benefit from the liquid dispersion of the powders. This fact supports the similarity or even the better properties attained by CPP in comparison with CCT and, simultaneously, highlights the importance of powders packing and the homogeneity in the final properties of the sintered ceramics. As an example, Ganesh et al. 2011 [51] prepared alumina-zirconia composites with relative densities in the range of 96-98 % by UP of freeze-dried granules, being the granules obtained from a well-dispersed and stabilized suspension containing 35 vol% of the solid’s mixture. Besides freeze granulation, spray drying is another way to obtain feedstock for CPP processes [99,168]. Recently, Hohne et al. 2020 [52] reported ultrasound atomization as an advanced spray granulation process to obtain alumina, zirconia and ZTA granules with proper properties for pressing (size distribution, homogeneity, flowability). Using 100 MPa as uniaxial pressure, RD values of 98.9 % and 99.8 % were obtained for alumina and ZTA composites sintered at 1580 °C for 1 h, respectively and RD of 99.1 % for zirconia sintered at 1500 °C for 0.5 h. Additionally, grain size, grain size distribution and size homogeneity are microstructural features that can influence the mechanical performance of the final materials. As observed in Fig. 3, for a given composition, the median grain size is similar for the different processing methods (CPP and CCT). For all compositions and processing methods, the variability on grain size among entries is small, except for the size of alumina grains in pure alumina ceramics (0 ZrO2 vol%) for both CPP and CCT methods. Comparing the grain size of alumina and zirconia, the results are consistent with the particle size of raw materials, i.e., smaller median grain sizes are observed for zirconia. Median Gr values of alumina are in the range of 0.5-1.8 μm for all compositions, while median Gr values of zirconia are around 0.5 μm. 4.1.3.2 Slip casting and gel casting Comparing slip casting (SC) and gel casting (GC) from CCT techniques for a given material, similar final mechanical properties have been reported in the literature since both techniques can benefit from the use of high-concentrated colloidal-based suspensions. Both techniques have RD values exhibiting lower dispersion (i.e. generally lower standard deviations, Table 3) when compared to the CPP processes. For all SC studies, PS of alumina and zirconia raw powders was lower than 1 μm, and only 3 entries reported particles with a size in the range 1-1.4 μm (one alumina entry in the work by Cho et al. 2020 [311] and two zirconia entries with particle sizes in the range 1-1.9 μm reported by Hassanin et al. 2013 [78]). For all GC studies, 10 entries reported the use of alumina raw powders with a size larger than 1 μm (in the range 1-7.5 μm) [187,253,254,258], while 12 entries used zirconia particles in the range 1-5 μm [117,253,324]. The literature supports that, in both SC and GC processes, proper particle packing combined with high stability of the suspension throughout time is extremely important to avoid particle segregations and consequently cracks occurring during the drying step [75,250,325]. Stability and high solids loading in suspensions are also crucial to achieve high structural performance after sintering, usually obtained by the addition of dispersants [75,250,325]. From the database and for all materials (alumina, zirconia and composites), 157 entries used suspensions with solids loading ≥ 50 vol% in GC [121,126,130,187,188,194,213,226,253,254,257–264,266–269,271–288,306,307,309,310], while only 16 entries with solids loading ≥ 50 vol% were found in SC [78,218,289,291,293,295,312,315]. Suspensions with solids loading ≤ 30 vol% (79 database entries for SC and GC, all compositions) are usually associated to nanometric particle sizes, since it is more difficult to disperse powders with high surface area, turning to high shrinkage values [74–77,79–84,88,123,125,127,128,150,174,178,290,304,312,315,317,321,326]. Although SC could benefit from the absence of organic additives during the sintering step when compared to GC, the green packing homogeneity preserved in GC could be a distinctive gain. This advantage can be particularly valuable in the processing of powder mixtures, such as ZTA or ATZ composites. As an example, Olhero et al. 2009 [218] prepared two different zirconia-alumina composites (70 wt% Al2O3 + 30 wt% ZrO2 and 40 wt% Al2O3 + 60 wt% ZrO2) by different techniques including SC and GC. For the same ZTA composition, the samples consolidated by GC and sintered for 1 h at 1600 °C had their alumina and zirconia grains uniformly distributed over the composite, which improved the mechanical properties in particular flexural strength, in comparison with those consolidated by SC. Likewise, Zhang et al. 2012 [208] obtained ZTA ceramics with a mass ratio of 3:1 (Al2O3:ZrO2) by acrylamide-based GC. The sintered samples (at 1600 °C for 2 h) presented an RD around 98.5 %, 643.3 ± 75 MPa as bending strength and 6.3 ± 0.3 MPa.m1/2 of fracture toughness. Abbas et al. 2015 [177] prepared ZTA samples (around 83 vol% and 17 vol% as alumina and YSZ proportions) reaching maximum RD around 99.1 %, maximum hardness 1902 HV, fracture toughness 5.43 MPa.m1/2 and flexural strength around 618 MPa when sintered at 1650 °C for 2 h. Osmotic drying and high solids loading in suspensions (62 vol%) were highlighted as the main benefits to achieve such properties. Disadvantages resultant from the binder burnout of organic additives in GC are also pointed out to explain the deterioration of the final structural properties of alumina- and zirconia-based ceramics. As an example, Liu et al. 2014 [59] prepared zirconia samples by GC using an epoxy resin and hardener as gel-forming agents. The zirconia solids content and epoxy resin varied between 30 to 45 vol% and 15 to 30 wt%, respectively. After sintering at 1550 °C for 2 h, RD was not higher than 90 %, which could be attributed to defects generated during the drying step and difficult burnout, due to the presence of organic compounds. The use of natural polymers as gelling agents, such as polysaccharides (agarose, carrageenan, arabic gum) rather than acrylamide-based and epoxy-based systems also started to be explored in the early 2000s. Santacruz et al. 2005 [273] used agarose as gel former (natural gel casting) to prepare high concentrated alumina suspensions (50, 55 and 57 vol%) leading to RD values higher than 99 % when sintered at 1500 °C for 2 h [273]. Zhang et al. 2014 [271] prepared alumina suspensions containing 55 vol% solids loading with optimized amounts of gellan gum and achieved sintered bodies (1550 °C for 2 h) with RD around 98 % and bending strength of approximately 330 MPa. Zhang et al. 2014 [271] prepared alumina suspensions containing 55 vol% solids loading with optimized amounts of gellan gum and achieved sintered bodies (1550 °C for 2 h) with RD around 98 % and bending strength of approximately 330 MPa. As in CPP processing, several reports also evaluate the effect of sintering temperature and time in the final density of ceramics obtained by CCT, which explains the high standard deviations in ST presented in Table 3, for alumina (0 ZrO2 vol%) and zirconia (100 ZrO2 vol%) made-up by SC. As an example, Abi et al. 2013 [176] dispersed alumina in an aqueous medium using HCl to stabilize a suspension with 43 vol% of solids. When the slip casting samples were sintered at 1400 °C for 2 h, only 90 % of RD was attained, while increasing sintering temperature to 1600 °C, RD increased up to 95 %. Ramesh et al. 2000 [87] prepared alumina-zirconia ceramics by slip casting using suspensions with 45 vol% solid content and 0.1-0.2 wt% (related to solid content) of polyacrylate as the dispersant. Three sintering temperatures were tested (1450, 1500 and 1550 °C), and the lowest RD values (81-89 %) were found for samples rich in alumina and sintered at 1450 °C. By increasing ST to 1500 and 1550 °C in similar samples, RD enhanced to values in the range of 94-100 %. 4.1.3.3 Influence of HIP Finally, Table 4 presents the same results as in Table 3 for the database entries that used HIP as the additional high-tech sintering procedure. As expected, there is a much lower number of entries reporting the use of HIP when compared to conventional sintering (CS), in a total of 127 entries (Table 4) against 827 entries for CS (Table 3). Being a time-consuming and expensive process, HIP is not extensively applied. Literature revision brings evidence that the use of HIP is more common in CPP technologies (total of 120 entries) than in CCT (total of 7 entries in SC and no entries in GC). For CPP, 27 entries have been collected for alumina, 34 for zirconia and 59 for composites, where most of the composites are processed solely by HIP (“Others” class in CPP). For a given material, sintering temperature in HIP processes (Table 4) tends to be lower than in CS (Table 3), although the material is commonly subjected to two sintering steps, one as CS at a higher temperature and a lower holding time and then the HIP step conditions. PS of zirconia raw powders are in the range [0.01,0.07] μm (n=57) in both processes CCT (n=3) and CPP (n=54), while alumina PS are in the interval [0.1,12.73] μm (n=113, with n=7 for CCT). The 9 database entries presenting PS > 1 μm [247,248], explains the high mean and s.d. values for 100 % alumina (0 vol% ZrO2) obtained by UP + HIP (Table 4). According to the results presented in Table 4, regardless of the shaping technology, the use of HIP in sintering leads to RD values higher than 99 %, with consequent improvements in mechanical properties. Flexural strength and fracture toughness are the structural properties where high improvements are noticeable for zirconia and composites rich in zirconia ([80,100[ ZrO2 vol%). Zirconia ceramics obtained by CPP techniques present mean FS around 850 MPa (Table 3) while FS values higher than 1300 MPa can be obtained with HIP (Table 4). As an example, Hu et al. 2018 [64] attained 3pt FS of 1780 MPa for zirconia stabilized with 3 mol% Y2O3, in a sample with 99 % of RD and 0.138 μm of average grain size in the final microstructure, by pre-sintering the samples in an oxygen atmosphere at 1275 °C for 2 h and HIP at 1450 °C for 4 h under an argon pressure of 200 MPa. Fracture toughness of zirconia could be improved from mean values around 7 MPa.m1/2 (Table 3) up to 10 MPa.m1/2 (Table 4, [165]). For alumina (0 ZrO2 vol%) and composites rich in alumina (]0,20] ZrO2 vol%), the reported average values for H in CPP samples are in the range 15-17 GPa (Table 3) and increase to the order of 19 GPa when HIP is used (Table 4, [212,239]). The same trend is noticeable for SC samples when HIP is applied after shaping, even if for a small number of entries [86,305,313]. Although enhancements were also expected in Young’s modulus, this property was reported only in one paper that used CIP combined with HIP in alumina, leading to an average of 398.0 ± 4.1 GPa (n=4) (Table 4, [246]). However, this value is larger than that obtained for the 3 alumina database entries using CIP and not HIP showing an E of 360.7 ± 8.1 GPa (n=3) (Table 3, [294]), thus supporting the expected trend on Young’s modulus. 4.2 Additive Manufacturing (AM) techniques According to the current ISO standard, AM comprises seven categories based on feedstock state (powder, liquid, suspension or sheets) and the deposition method [327,328]. Table 5 presents a general overview and classification of these AM categories, including BJ (a liquid bonding agent that is selectively deposited to join the powders), PBF (thermal energy selectively fuses regions of a powder bed), DED (focused thermal energy is used to fuse materials by melting), MJ (droplets of build material are selectively deposited), VP (liquid photopolymer in a vat is selectively cured by light-activated polymerization), ME (material is selectively dispensed through a nozzle or orifice) and SL (sheets of material are bonded together to form a 3D object). Table 5 includes the reference to the technologies highly used in ceramic materials, within each AM category, arranged into powder- and suspension-based technologies (according to the form of feedstock material). In this topic, it is worthwhile to mention that the categories initially developed aiming solely at powder processing, namely BJ and PBF, have now been opened to include suspension-based procedures in their processing routes, such as Layer-wise Slurry Deposition (LSD) and Suspension-based Selective Laser Sintering (S-SLS, or Suspension-based indirect Laser Sintering, S-iLS) [329,330], trying to mimic the good properties of the final materials produced by suspension-based technologies. Table 5 also resumes some of the advantages and disadvantages of each AM category, based on key features such as the ability to produce complex parts, mechanical properties of the final material, surface finishing, manufacturing costs and amount of material waste. The success of these AM techniques to produce ceramic materials is based on the feedstock material form, energy source and material deposition process, which are factors that highly influence the surface finishing, printing resolution and resultant mechanical properties of the final parts. On the other hand, in the ceramic parts construction via AM techniques, an anisotropic behaviour is implicit and, sometimes, the complexity of physical phenomena involved can limit the potential to produce high strength materials, being necessary to control and optimize patterns, properties’ variation, and the in-service behaviour of the produced components. The AM categories presented in Table 5 can also be classified into direct, including DED and a direct PBF technique, Selective Laser Melting (SLM), or indirect processing (including BJ, indirect PBF, MJ, VP, ME and SL) [27], depending on if a single-step or a multi-step procedure is involved to obtain the final component. Indirect processing is the most used since most of the AM techniques use a sacrificial binder material to shape the part and require post-processing steps such as de-binding and sintering. As all categories and technologies have been deeply discussed in previous review papers [12,15,16,27], this paper presents just a brief description of the technologies highly prone to dense ceramics fabrication. Binder Jetting (BJ), initially named 3D printing and now aka powder-based BJ, was developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the late 80s. In this process, 3D structures are constructed by droplets deposition of a liquid binding agent onto a powder bed of a ceramic powder, usually with coarse particle size [332]. The binder penetrates the powder bed by capillarity joining the ceramic particles and, in this way, forming a pattern with the required shape. BJ has been highly explored for plaster material as moulds or parts, often requiring post-processing to improve the desired strength or final characteristics [254,333]. The slurry-based BJ appears to introduce the advantages of colloidal ceramic processing into the technology [27,331]. Layer-wise slurry deposition (LSD) is a suspension-based BJ technology developed by a research group at the Federal Institute for Materials Research and Testing (BAM) in Germany [329], which is based on the spreading of a ceramic slurry employing a doctor blade instead of using a dry powder. The ceramic slurry contains small amounts of alginic acid sodium salt that is crosslinked by jetting a binder solution consisting of copper sulfate pentahydrate dissolved in ethylene glycol. Less porosity and, consequently, better mechanical properties have been appointed as the main advantages of LSD when compared to powder-based BJ [329]. Powder Bed Fusion (PBF) encompasses indirect powder-based Selective Laser Sintering (P-SLS, also known as P-iLS) technology and Selective Laser Melting (SLM) as single-step or direct powder bed fusion technology [27,331]. In P-SLS, the ceramic powder is mixed with a low melting point binder phase (polymeric or inorganic) and a local sintering of the mix is performed through melting of the binder by the laser beam. The binder provides a solid matrix upon re-densification of ceramic powder, ensuring the layer-by-layer formation of a green body that needs to be subsequently sintered. In the case of SLM, a laser selectively scans a powder bed layer-by-layer to fuse the material, to obtain sintered ceramic parts in a single step. Here, it is the ceramic material itself rather than a low melting point binder that is sintered/melted by the laser beam. The surface roughness of the ceramic parts, the high energy-consuming and the thermal stresses caused by the deposition of the cold layers of powder on top of the preheated powders have been appointed as the main weaknesses of these technologies. Suspension-based indirect laser sintering (S-SLS or S-iLS) includes the Ceramic Laser Sintering (CLS) technology developed by Tang et al. 2006 [334]. This technique uses a paving device that enables the deposition of a slurry containing finer ceramic particles suspended in a liquid carrier. It was first developed to build ultra-thin layers from aqueous-based colloidal suspensions containing silica, silica sol, and volcanic clay as an inorganic binder (low melting point). Later on, Tang et al. 2011 adapted this technology to produce dense alumina ceramics [330].
