Since P-SLS is more explored than S-SLS in ceramics, it is common to use only the SLS terminology, which is usually associated with powder-based selective laser sintering. The main technology used in ceramics from Direct Energy Deposition (DED) category is Laser Engineering Net Shaping (LENS), a single-step AM technology [335]. In the LENS process, the powder is supplied coaxially to the focus of a high-power laser beam, where a molten pool is subsequently formed on the substrate. Fast deposition and required minimal materials pre-processing are appointed as the main advantages. As in SLM, high thermal gradients and extremely fast cooling rates result in the development of thermal stresses, which usually induce delamination and cracking in ceramic materials. Material Jetting (MJ) is a suspension-based AM category where Inkjet Printing (IJP, also referred to as Direct Inject Printing, DIP) is the widespread technology for ceramics, namely prototypes, providing an excellent level of details, high accuracy and smooth surface finish in the parts. IJP disposes of two liquids, i.e. the ceramic particles with the photopolymer liquid and the support liquid, being the ceramic part constructed by thin layers of droplets cured by UV light [336]. Due to the very small volume of the feedstock material (ink/suspension) used in the current commercial printers, this technique is limited to print miniaturized ceramic parts, being mostly explored for porous alumina ceramics [16] with just a few results for high-density structural ceramics [337,338]. Another technology belonging to the MJ category is Pressurized Spray Deposition (PSD) developed by HotEnd Works LLC (Ohio, USA), where the slurry formulation is heated and pressurized for spraying deposition and the binder co-deposited from a second nozzle as the support material [27,339]. Vat Photopolymerization (VP) is another AM suspension-based category highly used in ceramics, invented in the early 1980s by Japanese and French researchers [340–342]. Current VP technologies highly used in ceramics include Stereolithography (SLA) and Digital Light Processing (DLP) [343], both relying on a similar operation principle, i.e. use of light, typically in the UV region of the spectrum, to cure a photosensitive viscous resin loaded with ceramic particles. The main SLA and DLP differences count on the printer’s design and light projection. While SLA makes use of a laser to deliver a concentrated amount of light in each spot of the resin’s monomers to induce photopolymerization, DLP is not restricted to a single spot and the entire layer is formed at once. Beyond SLA and DLP, different names and abbreviations are used for VP technologies in ceramic materials, including the Lithography-based Ceramic Manufacturing (LCM) introduced by Schwentenwein and Homa 2015 [344], a commercial DLP technology developed by Lithoz GmbH [27,345]. The great benefits of these technologies are the high printing resolution and excellent surface finishing, imperative for the fine details in ceramic parts. In Material Extrusion (ME) category, the 3D parts are constructed layer-by-layer from continuous material extrusion, which is selectively dispensed in the specific and desired coordinates through a nozzle or an orifice. Extrusion-based methods are known for their simplicity and low-cost fabrication. The processing simplicity and low manufacturing costs together with small amounts of organics needed and reduced material wasted during the processing are the key features of its popularity. The ME category includes Fused Deposition of Ceramics (FDC), also known as Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) or Fused Deposition Modelling (FDM), where the ceramic particles are dispersed into a thermoplastic (or wax) material to form a filament. Layer by layer, the flexible filament is partially melted and extruded through a moving deposition head onto a static worktable. Another extrusion method highly popular in ceramics is the Robocasting (RC) (aka Direct Write Assembly, DWA or Direct Ink Writing, DIW), patented by Dr. Cesarano and Prof. Calvert in 2000 [346]. It is based on the printing of slurry-based inks or pastes, typically containing high loads of ceramic particles dispersed in liquid medium (usually aqueous) with low-binder contents when compared to FFF or even SLA/DLP techniques. The ceramic inks should present specific rheological properties, namely shear-thinning behaviour to guarantee a continuous flow through the nozzle and viscoelastic properties to assure weight support of filaments during printing. Upon deposition, the ink should present excellent shape recovery capacity, retaining the extruded shape meaning a typical solid-like behaviour with high elastic/storage modulus [347]. Polymeric and thermo-curable additives are usually used to attain this proper rheological behaviour during printing and to avoid deformations throughout the ME process. More recently, other variants of extrusion-based techniques have been developed based on an intermediate step of layer consolidation, such as the Ceramic On-Demand Extrusion (CODE) [143]. In this technique, the ink is extruded on a tank with paraffin/oil to preclude undesirable water evaporation in the printed part, and the oil level is controlled during the printing process to reach just the top surface of the last deposited layer. Then, infrared radiation is applied to dry the last layer uniformly, repeating the process until print the full piece, followed by a drying step at controlled conditions and finishing with a sintering step. The advantages of this technique are shared with Robocasting, namely (i) the possibility to use fine ceramic powders that facilitates the sintering process, (ii) high solids loading paste resulting in a dense green body, (iii) printing at room temperature, and (iv) partial drying during the printing process, precluding cracks formation and enabling strong bonding between layers [12,27,110]. Oppositely, two main limitations have been recognized in both Robocasting and CODE techniques, namely significant staircase effect and difficulty in fabricating fine features in complex parts. Finally, Sheet Lamination (SL) encompasses Laminated Object Manufacturing (LOM) technology, developed in the 1980s by Helisys Corporation. This technology allows the production of objects from sheets as feedstock, usually green tapes produced by tape casting, in the case of ceramics. Ceramics LOM works by sequentially stacking, cutting and bonding these tapes to form the required shape. Although it is a very low-cost process with little post-processing and no support structures being required, SL is limited in the production of complex overhangs structures, where high amounts of wastes not reusable/recyclable are produced from the material that is removed in each layer during fabrication [348,349]. On the other hand, the main downside of SL is the presence of interfacial discontinuity and defects leading to delamination, differential shrinkage and interfacial porosity, which preclude the choice of this technology to attain high-density ceramics [27]. In the fabrication of dense bulk alumina- and zirconia-based ceramics, all categories have been studied with high emphasis for the powder-based category PBF and suspension-based categories VP and ME (recall the number of database entries per AM categories presented in Table 2). As evidenced by the literature search supporting this paper, SL is not a popular AM technology to produce alumina- or zirconia-based dense ceramic materials (only 1 entry in the database in 2001) due to the above-mentioned reasons. 4.2.1 Mechanical performance by powder- and suspension-based AM technologies Similar to the conventional consolidation techniques, AM technologies can be divided into powder- and suspension-based, by taking into consideration the form of the feedstock material (see Table 5). The bulk solid-based methods as FFF were included in the suspension-based group, since the fabrication of the filament (feedstock) involves dispersing the powders in a polymeric dispersion medium, namely a wax-based system. Similarly, the SL category is here considered as suspension-based since the green sheets as feedstock (fabricated by tape casting) are usually prepared in a liquid binder carrier. Following the results already presented for CPP and CCT, Table 6 shows the overall properties of the final materials produced by AM taking into account the reported experimental conditions, distinguishing the powder- from the suspension-based entries of the database. There is a total of 359 AM entries, from which 2 are associated with AM fabrication combined with HIP. For the non-HIP entries, Table 6a reveals that AM suspension-based techniques, highly comprised in VP and ME categories, have been vastly studied in the fabrication of dense alumina, zirconia, or even ZTA/ATZ composites fabrication. There is a total of 240 suspension-based entries [45,56,62,96,97,100–104,106–108,110,132,143,294,344,347,349–358], 229 of which report RD, 122 report FS (3 or 4 pt), 111 report H and 73 KIc. For the same materials, AM powder-based technologies collected a total of 117 entries [63,70,113,114,116,136,140,141,184,210,220–225,227,324,333,359–374], associated with experimentation in BJ, PBF and DED categories. From this total number of entries, 99 reported RD, while only 32, 36 and 23 entries have reported FS, H and KIc, respectively. These numbers are following represented in Fig. 4 . Similar to CPP and CCT techniques, Young’s modulus is the mechanical property fewer times reported in AM manuscripts. The previous numbers evidence that slurry-based AM technologies have been preferred to powder-based AM in the fabrication of technical ceramics. As a matter of fact, the AM fabrication of ceramic parts using powders as feedstock typically results in less dense ceramics, explaining the choice for other alternatives when the production target is functional ceramics, where high density and enhanced final properties are crucial. This is highlighted with the median RD values presented in Fig. 5 , for the comparison between powder-based (blue colour) and suspension-based (pink) AM technologies with the corresponding conventional processes (CPP and CCT). The RD differences among AM and conventional processes are highly pronounced for alumina or zirconia ceramics, rather than for the composites (for which fewer results are presented in literature). Mean RD for alumina and for zirconia obtained by AM powder-based is, respectively, 70.3 ± 19.6 % (n=59) and 74.6 ± 19.6 % (n=34) while, for AM suspension-based, the corresponding values are 90.6 ± 13.4 % (n=110) and 96.0 ± 5.8 % (n=96). Concerning alumina/zirconia composites, both powder- and suspension-based AM presented high RD values with low standard deviations estimated from a much lower number of experiments (total of 31 entries for all mixtures). As previously mentioned and, in good agreement with the literature results for CPP and CCT technologies, densification behaviour is related to the sintering conditions as well as to the PS of raw materials. According to Table 6a, the average PS of raw powders used in powder-based AM technologies is, in general, expressively higher than those used in suspension-based AM, for a given composition, which explains the lower average values of RD, FS and KIc obtained for powder-based AM materials. It should be noted, however, that the standard deviation of PS is particularly large for powder-based AM techniques (ranging from 16.77 to 33.37, Table 6a) evidencing the existence of experiments using atypical PS values. Given the (larger) sample size, the attention in the PS analysis is focused on PS used in pure alumina and zirconia experiments. Fig. 6 shows the distribution of the PS values per process and per mixture, in a PS axis that is zoomed in the [0,5] μm interval. Regarding the powder-based AM processes, there are 13 entries (n=58) with PS Al2O3 values between 8 and 74 μm [333,359,369,372,374,375] and 17 entries (n=33) with PS ZrO2 values between 14 and 60 μm [116,136,140,256], not shown in Fig. 6. These atypical values impact differently in the PS Al2O3 and PS ZrO2 distributions for the pure materials produced by powder-based AM technologies. In particular, the average and the median differ substantially for PS Al2O3 while, for PS ZrO2, they are similar. Thus, even if the standard deviation is high for both PS Al2O3 and PS ZrO2 (Table 6a), the interquartile range (a measure of dispersion based on the 50 % most central data) is much smaller for PS Al2O3 and as large as for PS ZrO2 (Fig. 6) than the corresponding standard deviations. Finally, when compared to CPP, the PS Al2O3 (PS ZrO2) values tend to be lower (much higher) for the pure materials produced by powder-based AM technologies (Fig. 6). Regarding the suspension-based AM technologies, both PS Al2O3 and PS ZrO2 show typically lower averages and lower standard deviations across compositions when comparing to powder-based AM entries (Table 6a). Also, these descriptive measures are more in accordance with, respectively, the medians and interquartile ranges (Fig. 6). This concordance is due to the lower number of entries with atypical PS values, exhibiting lower (discrepant) values. As an instance of that, and focusing on the pure materials, there are 7 entries (n=94) with PS Al2O3 values between 6 and 11 μm [343,376–378] and solely one entry (n=56) with PS ZrO2 equal to 44 μm [379]. Finally, when compared with CCT, the PS Al2O3 (PS ZrO2) values tend to be higher (lower) for the pure materials produced by suspension-based AM technologies (Fig. 6). Considering temperature and time conditions, in general, mean values are similar to those used in CCT and CPP (Table 3) and likewise more dependent on the material composition than on the AM processing methodology used. Also, for a given composition, mechanical properties attained by suspension-based AM are closer to the mean values reported for CCT techniques (Table 3), even if exhibiting high variability (which is deeply discussed in Section 4.2.2). Fig. 7 compares the flexural strength (the most reported mechanical property in AM) obtained in powder-based and suspension-based AM ceramics with the conventional processes (CPP and CCT). As expected, FS values are lower for powder-based than for CPP, even if just a few powder-based AM papers report FS for alumina or zirconia. There were no FS values in powder-based AM entries for the alumina/zirconia mixtures. The scenario is different when comparing the FS values obtained from suspension-based AM and CCT processes. Besides being more times reported (in comparison with powder-based processes), the FS values attained for AM-suspension are closer to those obtained for CCT, for a given material. The highest suspension-based AM and CCT difference is observed for pure zirconia ceramics, also exhibiting a high variability in the observed FS values. These results can be driven by the nature and the amount of stabilizing agents used in the processing. As above-mentioned, cubic zirconia stabilized with 8 mol% Y2O3 (8YSZ) usually presents lower FS and KIc values, when compared to partially stabilized tetragonal zirconia. To corroborate this decrease in performance with the database, some of the results presented in Table 3 and Table 6a were recalculated by ignoring the 8YSZ entries (49 out of 1313 entries). These entries correspond to the production of 100 % ZrO2 ceramics and not applying HIP in the production process: 8 entries in CPP [120,157,159], 27 in CCT [120,130,152,155] and 14 in AM [68,132,139,140,145]. When removing the 8YSZ entries, FS (4pt) changed from 553.2 ± 221.4 (n=8) to 652.7 ± 144.7 MPa (n=6) and KIc changed from 4.3 ± 1.0 (n=33) to 4.5 ± 1.0 MPa.m1/2 (n=27) in the suspension-based AM entries (Table 6a). Despite the small number of 8YSZ AM entries, the 8YSZ impact is clear for AM processes as for both FS and KIc, the average increased while the variability decreased for FS. The same trend is observed for the conventional processing techniques (Table 3) e.g. where KIc changes from 5.4 ± 2.4 (n=9) to 6.8 ± 1.5 MPa.m1/2 (n=6) in CPP/UP and from 12.2 ± 7.5 (n=28) to 13.7 ± 7.0 MPa.m1/2 (n=24) in CCT/GC (Table 3). 4.2.1.1 Influence of HIP As previously referred and showed in Table 6b, the use of HIP was identified in two of the AM selected papers [370,380], one in powder-based AM (referred to alumina samples printed by SLS) and another in suspension-based AM (referred to Robocasting in alumina ceramics) (Table 6b). Liu et al. 2013 [370,380] introduced CIP and HIP in alumina parts produced by indirect SLS to improve final density. The authors prepared a granulated powder by spray drying using Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and epoxy resin as a binder phase for the SLS process. After printing, alumina samples (green parts) presented 32 % of relative density that increased to 52.4 % after CIP and, finally, attained 96 % after conventional sintering and HIP. This density value is the highest of the database for samples obtained by the indirect powder-based SLS technique. Mamatha et al. 2018 [380] produced alumina by Robocasting using methylcellulose and Poliethyleglycol (PEG) as thickening agents to prepare the extrudable paste. Pressureless sintered samples at 1650 °C for 1 h presented maximum RD of 98 % and 15 GPa of H, while HIPed samples exhibited RD around 99.7 % and 18 GPa of H, even at low temperature (1350 °C). Fine-grained microstructure, due to the enhanced diffusion caused by the pressure during HIP even at low sintering temperature and the flaws elimination have been appointed as the main reasons for the superior density and mechanical properties in printed samples by Robocasting using HIP in the sintering process. 4.2.2 Mechanical performance by AM categories and technologies The comparison between AM categories starts by exploring the values of the most reported variable among literature experiments, i.e. the RD of the final materials. Fig. 8 displays the RD values obtained for alumina, zirconia and their composites produced from several AM technologies. There are 172 and 136 database entries, respectively for dense alumina and dense zirconia ceramics, in which 168 and 130 report the RD values. Overall, Fig. 8 shows that zirconia ceramics exhibit a higher median RD value than alumina ceramics for all categories. Concerning the different AM categories, BJ and PBF exhibit the lowest median RD values while DED, VP and ME exhibit the highest, for both materials. Also, the RD distribution for BJ, PBF and MJ-based experiments exhibits the highest variability for alumina when compared to zirconia. Finally, there are 50 entries concerning alumina and zirconia mixtures, 31 of which report RD values for PBF, DED, VP and ME-based experiments. Alumina/zirconia composites are less studied in AM, without entries for BJ or MJ. The sample median RD values are above 95 %, except for the single entry in ME for which the RD was 85 % (mixture in ]20,80[ ZrO2 vol%, see Table 7 ). Complementary to the previous representations, Table 7 resumes the experimental conditions (PS of raw materials, ST and t) as well as the relative density and mechanical properties for the database entries for the different AM categories and technologies. The mean PS of raw materials used in BJ, PBF and DED categories (predominantly powder-based) is larger than that used for the remaining AM categories (most suspension-based), which is in good agreement with the powder versus suspension comparison presented in Table 6. Regarding ST, AM processes use higher temperatures for alumina (or compositions rich in alumina) than for zirconia, similarly to the CCT and CPP trends (Table 3), emphasizing that AM is following the knowledge acquired in the conventional processing related to the sintering ability of alumina- and zirconia-based materials. BJ and PBF are also the AM categories where the mechanical characterization of the printed samples is highly scarce. This scenario is analogous for all other AM categories (see Table 7), being FS the highest reported mechanical property (153 out of 358 AM entries) with a high number of entries in VP (76 out of 140 VP entries) and ME (35 out of 72 ME entries) for all studied materials. As for CPP and CCT entries, Young’s modulus (E) is the least reported property in AM studies (34 out of 358 AM entries). To examine the reported results and related strategies that have been used to improve the performance of final AM ceramics, a more detailed description by category and respective technologies, supported by the results presented in Fig. 8 and Table 7, is following presented. 4.2.2.1 Binder Jetting Concerning the BJ category, the 29 database entries are concentrated in single-component materials. In the 17 alumina entries only 3 reported FS, 2 reported H and 2 reported E, while 9 out of 12 entries in zirconia characterized FS of the final ceramics, without any entries for other properties (H, E and KIc). With respect to the number of entries per technology in the BJ category, 27/29 of the entries are related to the BJP technology [113,333,360–362,372] and only 2/29 are LSD based experiments [329], which results explain the higher variability in RD observed for alumina than for zirconia (Table 7). The larger RD dispersion observed for alumina (71.5 ± 18.6 %, n=17, Table 7) is due to a few experiments leading to very low RD values of the final materials (58.9 ± 6.5 %, n=4) when using large Al2O3 raw-particle sizes (40 μm) to form the main structural component [333]. When alumina nanoparticles (PS < 50 nm) suspended in the printing liquid medium were used to incorporate this component to fill the inter-particle pores, the RD values increased. However, RD was not higher than 66 % for the highest nanoparticle concentration tested (15 wt%) [333]. On the other hand, high RD values were obtained both from LSD, with the suspension-based BJ technology (99.1 ± 0.6 %, n=2) [329], and from BJP, with the powder-based BJ technology (achieving 94.5 % by using PS of 0.3 μm and 16 h of sintering holding time) [362]. The (small) variability of BJ experiments observed for zirconia is obtained from 12 zirconia BJ entries that come from one single paper [381], studying different sintering temperatures (1400, 1500, 1600 °C) and using different additives. In that paper, Huang et al. 2019 [381] developed a novel inorganic colloidal binder from zirconium basic carbonate, as it easily decomposes by heat to form zirconia particles. This approach was compared to the conventional Polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) binder, which usually causes nozzle clogging problems. The results show that the final RD of the printed parts was not higher than 65 %, even when sintered at 1600 °C, although the average RD value was shown to be higher for the inorganic (56.9 ± 5.6 %, n=6) than for the PVP binder (51.4 ± 4.8 %, n=6) [381]. 4.2.2.2 Powder Bed Fusion For the PBF category, the results in Fig. 8 were already showing a quite large RD variability for the alumina experiments, which is partially explained by the variability observed among PBF technologies. As presented in Table 7, SLM and P-SLS technologies have been quite explored in ceramics (with, respectively, 18 and 42 entries out of the 61 PBF entries). As there is just 1 entry with an S-SLS experiment, the results of this PBF technology are not presented in Table 7. Concerning the mechanical characterization of alumina ceramic parts produced by PBF, 15 out of 37 entries reported FS and just one measured H. In zirconia, 4 out of 21 entries presented H, without reference to other mechanical properties. Since the powders are fully melted in SLM, superior mechanical properties are usually achieved with this technology when compared to SLS (see e.g. the H values for zirconia in SLM and P-SLS, Table 7). In accordance with this trend, SLM entries exhibit higher mean RD values in comparison with P-SLS experiments (Table 7), for alumina ceramics [141,324,364,365,367–371,382], zirconia ceramics [114,116,141,324] and mixtures of both [225]. Different strategies have been developed to attain complete powders melting in the SLM technique. Recently, Florio et al. 2019 [365] used SLM to produce alumina parts from alumina granules (as starting powder) doped with a small quantity of iron oxide (hematite), achieving RD values of 96.2 ± 0.5 % (n=18) and an average biaxial FS of 25 MPa with a maximum value of 38.1 MPa (n=8) (results on the biaxial flexural test are not presented in Table 7 due to the low number of database entries recorded for this property). On the other hand, Jan Wilkes et al. 2013 [225] developed alumina-zirconia ceramic parts (41.5 wt% zirconia and 58.5 wt% alumina, mixture ratio close to the eutectic point) from SLM (presented in [80, 100[ ZrO2 vol% class in Table 7), by melting completely the ceramic powders with the laser beam, attaining ~100 % for RD and 356 ± 182 MPa for biaxial FS (not shown in Table 7). This paper concluded that the use of a zirconia and alumina mixture has advantages when compared to the use of single-component materials, as a fine-grained eutectic microstructure can be obtained while preheating the powders to at least 1600 °C avoids crack formation [225]. Regarding P-SLS, organic and inorganic binder agents have been approved to form a liquid phase and to promote the diffusion and migration of ceramics, being the main concerns of high shrinkages and porosities on the final parts. Verga et al. 2020 [220] developed ATZ parts via P-SLS, where the powder was produced via a spray drying process and the laser-matter interaction was enhanced by binder pyrolysis. Relative densities around 90 % were achieved, although together with low FS values (31 MPa, n=1, 4pt bending test, [80,100[ vol% ZrO2 in Table 7). To overcome the low density and poor mechanical properties of ceramic components prepared by P-SLS (see Table 7 for details), post-processing methods (infiltration/isostatic pressing) have also been used. For example, Shahzad et al. 2014 [141] reported results on SLS of spherical polypropylene–zirconia composite powder using yttria-stabilized zirconia powder with nanometre size (30 nm). Homogeneous spherical composite powders in the form of microspheres with good flow characteristics were prepared, although the final sintered RD of the produced parts was around 36 % of the theoretical density. The RD increased to 54 % after infiltration of the previously printed samples with a zirconia-based aqueous suspension. Alternatively, Warm Isostatic pressing (aka WIP) was also applied to the printed samples without and with post-processing infiltration (with settings 135 °C and 64 MPa), allowing to increase RD after sintering to 92 % and 85 %, respectively [141]. The authors concluded that high-density samples presented cracks in the cross-section, while the combination of infiltration and WIP allowed producing crack-free samples, but with densities not higher than 85 %. As already mentioned in Section 4.2.1, the combination of CIP and HIP as post-processing methods was also explored in alumina parts printed by SLS, reaching 96 % of RD [370]. Finally, the suspension-based variation of SLS (S-SLS) (not displayed in Table 7) has shown the potential to produce high RD alumina ceramics (98.0 % for 1 entry) [330] by using submicron alumina powders (average size 0.5 μm) and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as sacrificial polymer binder. Firstly, fully hydrolyzed water-insoluble PVA was coated onto alumina particles. A slurry containing the coated alumina particles, water-soluble PVA as the binder, ammonium polymethacrylate as a dispersant and deionized water as suspending medium was prepared and sequentially paved, dried and laser-scanned. Both types of PVA react with laser irradiation, forming a water-insoluble mixture that bound the alumina particles. After sintering at 1600 °C for 2 h, printed parts presented a mean FS of 363.5 MPa, comparable with FS values attained for alumina by CPP or CCT techniques [330]. 4.2.2.3 Direct Energy Deposition The DED category presents entries solely based on LENS technology experiments that lead to the highest RD values among all AM categories and materials [136,184,210,221–224,227,359,363,373,374,383]. For certain materials, the values obtained for H and KIc (see Table 7, DED category) are comparable with those obtained by CPP and CCT (Table 3), while the FS values are still lower. The first report on LENS related to functional ceramics was presented by Balla et al. 2008 [363], where alumina parts were produced with cylinders, cubes and gear shapes achieving 94 % RD after fabrication. RD increased up to 97 % and 98 % when the alumina components were then submitted to a post-processing heat treatment at 1100 °C and 1600 °C during 5 h holding time, respectively. This is the only report where heat treatment after sintering in a direct AM technique was used, corresponding to the values reported as 1300 °C mean ST in Table 7. Niu et al. 2018 [359] claimed for the first time the possibility to obtain large-sized Al2O3 ceramic components by LENS with relative densities around 99.5 % and average flexural strength of 210 MPa. Besides pure alumina, effects of doping agents, such as TiO2 to obtain Al2O3/Al2TiO5 composite ceramics or even zirconia to obtain ZTA ceramics, have been the recent trends in this technique [383]. Recently, Pappas et al. 2020 [184] studied the doping effects of zirconia on laser-direct-deposited alumina ceramics. The authors concluded that the increase in zirconia content follows a greatly reduced critical flaw size, improving substantially flexural strength from 58 MPa (for the pure alumina samples) to 208 MPa (for samples printed with 10 wt% zirconia), while RD is around 96 %. 4.2.2.4 Material Jetting The database entries for the MJ category are distributed among IJP [45,48,56,139,337,338,384,385] and PSD [339] technologies, respectively with 23 and 2 entries out of 25 (Table 7). RD values around 95-96 % have been reported for zirconia printed by IJP [45,56,139]. For alumina, the RD has a lower average and higher variability (76.3 ± 21 %, n=18, Table 7) since, in most alumina studies, RD values did not exceed 90 % [338,384]. In accordance, FS reported for zirconia presents comparable values with those in CPP and CCT (Table 3) while, for alumina, the average FS is quite lower. The research developed in this topic [45,56] advocates that the properties of the fluid, determined by solids loading and PS of the raw powders, and accurate drop placement are important requirements to successfully manufacture ceramic parts by IJP. Ebert et al. 2009 [45] demonstrated the possibility to fabricate zirconia (3Y-TZP) with high strength (763 MPa) and toughness (6.7 MPa.m1/2) for dental applications by using a zirconia-based ceramic suspension with 27 vol% solid content with 90 nm particle size and a modified drop-on-demand inkjet printer. The authors integrated a tailored cleaning unit into the printer, which allows for longer printing periods without nozzle clogging. However, the microstructures of the printed and sintered samples were not completely free of process-related defects, presenting RD values lower than 96.9 % [45]. Özkol et al. 2012 [56] applied the DIP/IJP to fabricate 3Y-TZP parts by an aqueous ink containing 40 vol% of particles with 0.63 μm mean size. Relative densities around 96 % and flexural strength ∼843 MPa were reported for the printed and sintered specimens. With respect to alumina, Muniz et al. 2019 [338] studied the effects of using different binders (namely polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), polyvinyl acetate (PVAc) and arabic gum) on the structural properties of IJP parts, reporting RD values lower than 50 % after sintering at 1500 °C for 1 h, explaining the high variability of RD values in Table 7. Although proper solids loading in suspensions have been attained (45 vol%), both the high average PS of the alumina powder (3.68 μm) and the low ST could justify the low RD values obtained after sintering [338]. To overcome these drawbacks, sintering additives and additional CIP after printing have been reported as helpful procedures to achieve higher RD ceramics by IJP. As an example, Huang et al. 2020 [337] used a two-step sintering method (pre-sintering at 1150 °C and sintering at 1600 °C) and a precursor liquid infiltration treatment after pre-sintering to improve the density of the alumina parts printed by IJP. These actions allowed to attain a maximum RD of 95.2 % using a raw alumina powder with 5 μm mean particle size. 4.2.2.5 Vat Photopolymerisation As shown in Table 7, the VP category is the AM processing route with highest number of experiments reported in literature, with an overall number of 140 entries distributed as 79 entries for SLA [15,23,66,69,71,97,112,118,183,186,263,277,294,343,358,377,378,386–401], 58 for DLP [46,49,62,68,70,100,102–104,106–109,111,135,137,145,146,185,354,356,357,402,403] and 3 entries for LCM [98,228,344]. Since LCM has the basic principles of DLP, the results for the first technology are included in DLP in Table 7. As can be seen from Table 7, RD and mechanical properties reported for both SLA and DLP technologies are comparable with those attained by CPP and CCT techniques (Table 3). Furthermore, there are no relevant differences in the mechanical performance between the parts printed by SLA and DLP, due to the high similarity in the printing processing systems used in both technologies. Variability of RD for alumina parts (Fig. 8 and Table 7) is also smaller in VP when compared to BJ, PBF and MJ. The ceramic suspensions as feedstock for these technologies should include the photoresponsive components (organic matrix/resin) as the base matrix, to be polymerized upon absorption of a UV photon [404]. The incorporation of ceramic particles in this matrix usually decreases the photopolymerization reaction by scattering the UV light, and this effect is minimized when the refractive index of the ceramic filler is almost equal to that of the organic background. When the refractive index of the ceramic filler is superior, the UV light will be absorbed by the ceramic filler, reducing the curing depth. Similarly, ceramic particles with lower sizes reduce the light-curing reaction, due to scattering effects. Alumina and zirconia photosensitive suspensions for SLA/DLP technologies are already commercially exploited by several companies in the market, such as 3DCERAM (Limoges, France) and Sirris (Belgium), and these are commonly used as raw materials in some literature research [343]. Moreover, these technologies are well known for their excellent surface finishing and printing resolution in ceramics, difficult to attain by other AM technologies, with outstanding results for small reticulated alumina/zirconia pieces (complete piece not fully occupied with dense material) [12]. The scenario is different for full dense and large ceramic components. Because of the large amounts of organics (resin as photopolymer matrix), the printed components need to go through a slow and long de-binding step (to burn out the polymeric part) followed by a sintering stage (to achieve a proper structural resistance). Although this de-binding process could be easier in small and reticulated structures, it is critical for full dense and large parts, resulting in high cracks formation and distortions in final shape dimensions. Azarmi et al. 2019 [343] fabricated alumina parts from a commercial feedstock (3DCeram©). The organic component of the printed parts was burnout during 70-90 h at 1000 °C with subsequent sintering at 1200–1700° C for approximately 20 h, depending on the thickness of the samples. The resulting RD values did not exceed 95 % and no other mechanical properties have been reported. To fabricate a zirconia-based crown bridge model of a single missing tooth by SLA, Lian et al. 2019 [97] used suspensions with 40 vol% and 200 nm as the average particle size of zirconia powders and established 100 h for de-binding temperature profile. RD around 99 % was achieved after sintering the samples at 1500 °C for 1 h. Similarly, Xing et al. 2017 [390] prepared zirconia bars by SLA using a photosensitive acrylic resin suspension containing 55 vol% of ZrO2 particles with ~200 nm in diameter. The De-binding step was evaluated at 500 °C for 18 h followed by sintering at 1450 °C for 2 h, and produced zirconia bars with 99.3 % as RD, 1154 ± 182 MPa as FS, 6.37 ± 0.25 MPa.m1/2 as KIc, and 13.90 ± 0.62 GPa as H. Besides the duration of the de-binding process, other parameters, such as particle size of the ceramic powders and their volume fraction in the resin matrix, have been shown to influence the final density of alumina and zirconia ceramics produced by VP [100,377]. Wu et al. 2016 [377] suggested that the combination of a powder with a bimodal particle size distribution with a vacuum de-binding process, instead of traditional de-binding, offers an effective way to fabricate alumina samples by SLA. Jang et al. 2019 [100] evaluated the effect of volume fraction of zirconia suspensions in the microstructure and final properties of parts printed by DLP. Volume fractions in the range of 48-58 vol% were considered, being concluded that 58 vol% was the maximum possible for printing since the cure depth decreased as the volume fraction of zirconia particles increased. On the other hand, the number of cracks increased as solids loading of zirconia decreased, being attained a maximum 3pt bending strength of 674.74 ± 32.35 MPa for suspensions with 58 vol%, while RD was not higher than 93 %. Recently, Zhang et al. 2020 [62] tried to produce strengthened zirconia ceramics by DLP by introducing t-ZrO2 into m-ZrO2 as raw materials. The highest RD and 3pt FS attained were 96.4 % and 306.53 ± 6.03 MPa, respectively, when the tetragonal 3Y-TZP concentration was 7.5 vol% [62]. As expected, the authors concluded that FS was strongly dependent on the transformed amounts of monoclinic ZrO2. Besides the optimization of photosensitive suspensions’ features (e.g. composition and curing behaviour) and of de-binding and sintering conditions, additional procedures have been used to accomplish high density and high strength in bulk alumina or zirconia ceramics produced by VP. Some of these examples are microwave sintering [294], CIP after the de-binding step [354], liquid precursor infiltration [70] and different printing directions and/or geometry [387]. Besides pure alumina or zirconia, literature on the fabrication of alumina-zirconia composite ceramics by VP category has recently emerged [66,69,70,104,183,185,186,228]. Likewise, most of the works have been dedicated to study the effect of the rheological properties of the photocurable composite suspensions with different ratios of alumina/zirconia [104,185,186], printing strategies [228], proper de-binding processes, sintering temperatures and holding time [69], as well as the effect of particle size distribution [66] on printable conditions and final performance of the ceramic parts. Wu et al. 2017 [183] fabricated ZTA ceramics (alumina/zirconia 4:1) by SLA using raw materials with nanometre size. After sintering at 1600 °C during 4 h, the samples presented RD values of 99.5 %, H of 17.76 GPa, FS of 530 MPa, and KIc of 5.72 MPa.m1/2, which are values comparable to those for ceramics obtained through conventional ceramic processing (see Table 3). More recently, the same authors [70] proposed an integrated approach combining SLA/DLP and a liquid precursor infiltration to prepare alumina toughened zirconia composites. The ATZ samples produced with infiltration and post-CIP sintered at 1550 °C during 2 h hold RD around 98 %, H of 12.65 ± 0.24 GPa and KIc of 6.42 ± 0.33 MPa m1/2. Wu et al. 2018 [186] fabricated defect-free alumina-zirconia composites using SLA technique, followed by the application of a liquid drying and a two-step de-binding process. Full dense materials were attained when sintered at 1600 °C during 1 h. In resume, the main current drawbacks in the fabrication of dense alumina, zirconia ceramics or their composites by VP technologies are mainly related to the cure efficiency of the suspensions and the de-binding conditions. As a consequence, current research is mainly focused on developing photosensitive alumina and zirconia suspensions by fine-tuning their cure behaviour [405–407]. 4.2.2.6 Material Extrusion The ME category presents a total of 72 entries distributed by Robocasting (41 entries), CODE (17 entries), FFF (9 entries) and RC associated with FFF technology (RC + FFF, 5 entries). Concerning Robocasting (RC), the most studied materials have been alumina (21 entries) and zirconia (19 entries) with only 1 entry for composites (]20,80[ ZrO2 vol%). From Table 7, average RD values in RC are all between 95-99 % for alumina and zirconia materials, although the mechanical properties, particularly FS, are less reported and exhibit high variability between different studies when compared to CPP and CCT (Table 3). Several issues related to surface finishing, printing resolution and porosity inter-filaments are still to be solved. Feilden et al. 2016 [408] used hydrogel-based alumina inks with 36 vol% of solids to print simple 3D parts by RC, reaching 97 % of RD and 230 MPa of FS. The authors concluded that the defects resulting from the printing process limit the mechanical strength in many cases, and it depends on the orientation of the part with respect to the printing direction [408]. The properties of the final parts are also highly dependent on the ink’s behaviour, explaining the existence of several papers aimed to develop and optimize appropriate inks for RC [347,409–412]. The most common studied additives (thickening agents) for inks preparation in ceramics include polyethyleneimine (PEI), hydrogel of pluronic F-127, polyethylene glycol (PEG), polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and natural-based polymers such as carboxy methylcellulose (CMC) and hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC). Besides the nature and amounts of thickening agents used in inks, solids loading and particle size of raw powders are also important parameters in RC. As it can be seen in Table 7, PS for alumina powders used in RC is 0.53 ± 0.22 μm (n=19), in good agreement with the reported RD values. Regarding solids loading in suspensions, Rueschhoff et al. 2016 [351] optimized it to obtain near-net-shaped dense alumina ceramic components by RC. Alumina suspensions containing 53–56 vol% were found to produce the best printing performance and sintered parts (1600 °C for 1 h) with RD exceeding 98 %. The authors report FS values after sintering around 134 MPa and 157 MPa for suspensions with 53 and 55 vol%, respectively, being lower than expected and largely affected by the porosity introduced during the preparation of suspensions and not by the solids loading in suspensions. Jones et al. 2019 [302] showed the possibility to produce alumina armour targets via RC and compared them against a commercially available isostatically pressed (IP) armour formulation. The RC plates exhibited similar RD as the samples obtained by the traditional method (around 97 %) and exhibited increased H but lower FS when compared to the commercial IP material. High variability in FS results for RC samples was observed in this study, being reported an average 4pt bending strength around 234 MPa for RC samples against 267 MPa for IP [302]. Recently, Elizarova et al. 2020 [413] presented a novel paste composition (consisting in a solution of phenolic resin in methyl ethyl ketone and ceramic powders) that allows the shaping of the green bodies after printing. Robocasted alumina parts using this ink presented RD after sintering up to 95 %, likely due to binder burnout defects, and an FS value of 356 MPa (3-point bending strength) which is comparable with those of other techniques. Regarding zirconia fabrication by RC, Table 7 presents a quite high mean value for the raw-particle size, derived from one study (1 entry) where authors referred to 44 μm as the PS value of zirconia [379]. Removing this value, the average PS for zirconia raw powders was similar to that for alumina. As in alumina ceramics, the same constraints have been experienced in the ME processing of zirconia. Peng et al. 2018 [110] fabricated yttria-stabilized zirconia structures by RC using suspensions with 38 vol% as solids loading. Printed samples exhibited RD values higher than 94 %, hardness up to 13.29 GPa and flexural strengths up to 242.8 ± 11.4 MPa. High linear shrinkage values (33 %) were also reported, perhaps associated with the quite low solids concentration used in the pastes. Branco et al. 2020 [144] explored RC for the fabrication of zirconia-based pieces for dental applications and compared their performance with commercial zirconia samples processed by a traditional subtractive manufacturing method (as CPP, sintering and machining). AM zirconia samples obtained from an ink with 40 vol% of solids revealed to be less dense (around 98 % RD) than commercial samples, also showing lower hardness, toughness and wettability. While structural properties were still inferior to those of traditionally manufactured zirconia dental components, important advantages of RC have been highlighted, namely the processing easiness and the tribological performance. Yu et al. 2020 [101] used RC to print yttria-partially-stabilized zirconia with 60 vol% solids loading. After sintering at 1550 °C for 5 h, following a period at 1700 °C for 6 minutes, the FS, KIc and H of the parts produced were 488.96 ± 79.84 MPa (16 repetitions of the same experiment), 2.63 ± 0.2 MPa.m1/2 (n=16), and 11.52 ± 0.57 GPa (n=5), respectively. Shao et al. 2017 [119] proposed the production of zirconia parts by a new variant of the RC process, named 3D gel printing (included in RC, Table 7), by using 2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA) as the gelation system. The catalyst and initiator were fed into the screw extruder along with the slurry containing the ceramic particles to adjust the gelation time. After sintering at 1520 °C for 2 h, the RD, hardness and transverse rupture strength of the sintered zirconia parts were 97.6 %, 14.4 GPa and 450 MPa, respectively. Similarly, using a gelling suspension, Shi et al. 2020 [96] fabricated zirconia implanted teeth by extrusion-based printing and attained 98.5 %, 14.4 ± 0.1 GPa and 520 ± 20 MPa for RD, H and FS, respectively, after sintering at 1500 °C for 4 h. Alternatively to several gelling systems, binders and thickening agents, some authors tried to develop suitable inks for RC free of organic additives [124,355]. Hensen et al. 2018 [355] employed direct coagulation of alumina nanopowder slurries with the polyvalent salt tri-ammonium citrate to promote the solidification of the paste. Although RD higher than 97 % was reached after sintering at 1550 °C for up to 2 h, thin-walled parts have been printed which could explain the high variability of flexural modulus and less FS presented when compared to the commercial samples. Recently, Rodrigues et al. 2020 [124] reported the possibility to print zirconia-based dental pieces from pastes with high solids concentration in the 80-90 wt% range, just by using the optimal amount of dispersant. The optimal results were achieved for the paste with 88 wt%, resulting in sintered parts with 97.1 ± 0.8 % of RD, H of 14.46 GPa and KIc of 4.11 ± 0.09 MPa.m1/2 (n=5) [124]. Rather than inks optimization, post-processing methods, such as vacuum sintering and HIP, have been considered to reach very high densities (> 99 %) [380,414]. Carloni et al. 2020 [414] used vacuum sintering to obtain transparent alumina ceramics printed by RC. Mamatha et al. 2018 [380] increased RD of alumina samples printed by RC from 98 % (when pressureless sintered at 1650 °C for 1 h) to 99.7 % (when HIPed at 1350 °C using 165 MPa pressure). While promising mechanical properties have been attained for ceramics printed by RC, this technique still does not provide complete freedom of achievable printing shapes. To overcome this limitation, RC has been associated with other operating principles used in other techniques where shape complexity is easier to accomplish, such as SLA/DLP and FFF. Faes et al. 2016 [142] extruded zirconia suspensions in thermoplastic carriers containing a binder and further cured the deposited paste by continuous UV-light polymerization. Scheithauer et al. 2015 [134] developed an AM process that combines RC and thermoplastic 3D Printing (FFF/FDM). They used a thermoplastic binder system (a mixture of paraffin and beeswax) at 100 °C to prepare alumina (67 vol% solids) and zirconia (45 vol% solids). Sintered samples (alumina at 1600 °C, zirconia at 1500 °C) with a density of about 99 % were obtained, although only single-wall pieces were produced. A similar procedure (a combination of RC and thermoplastic printing) has been used by Promakhov et al. 2018 [217] to fabricate 80 % zirconia and 20 % alumina composites (not specified if in vol% or wt%). This was the single report of the systematic review concerning the fabrication of alumina/zirconia composites by RC (see Table 7). The authors verified that the temperature of the hot zone in the printing process critically affects the wall thickness and the quality of the printed samples. After sintering at 1500 °C for 1 h, samples presented around 15 % porosity, a quite high value that markedly affects the mechanical performance of the samples (450 ± 70 MPa as 3pt bending strength and 14 GPa as microhardness, see Table 7). Some limitations in RC could be overcome, or at least weakened, by using finer extrusion nozzles, however at the expense of increasing the overall fabrication time. Concerning CODE technology, more entries are presented for zirconia than for alumina (Table 7). In comparison with RC, RD values for zirconia ceramics produced by CODE exhibit higher average and lower variability (Table 7). Mean FS values for zirconia produced by CODE are still far from those attained in CCT and CPP techniques (Table 3). Oppositely, FS, H, E and KIc for alumina (Table 7) present average values highly comparable with those of the conventional processing (Table 3). Ghazanfari et al. 2017 [352] used the CODE technique to obtain alumina specimens from suspensions containing 60 vol% of solids. In that paper, the samples were reported to exhibit an RD value of 98 %, E of 371 ± 14 GPa (n=20), 364 ± 50 MPa (n=24) of FS, KIc of 4.5 ± 0.1 MPa.m1/2 (n=6) and a H value of 19.8 ± 0.6 GPa (n=20), after sintering at 1550 °C during 1.5 h. A total volume shrinkage of around 42 % was also stated [352]. In another paper [132], the same authors also considered CODE technology to produce yttria-stabilized zirconia (8YSZ) from pastes with 50 vol% of solids. Sintering parts at 1550 °C for 0.5 h and 2.5 h presented similar RD values (around 98 %). H and FS were respectively 15.3 ± 0.4 GPa (n=5) and 232 ± 55 MPa when sintered at 1550 °C for 0.5 h, and 14.5 ± 0.4 GPa (n=5) and 278 ± 59 MPa when the holding time increased to 2.5 h [132]. Li et al. 2018 [143] also used CODE to developed 3Y-TZP test specimens using pastes with solids loading > 50 vol% and evaluated the effect of the sintering conditions in the printed parts. When sintered at 1550 °C for 1 h holding time, final components presented RD higher than 99 %, H of 13.1 GPa and 3pt FS of 715 MPa. To achieve highly complex parts, Li et al. 2020 [65] reported the possibility to print 3Y-TZP samples by CODE using support structures of sacrificial materials, namely polycaprolactone, silicone and petrolatum. Petrolatum was identified as the most feasible support material. The shrinkages of sintered zirconia pieces after sintering at 1550 °C for 1 h ranged between 21.9 % and 22.8 %, with no significant anisotropic behaviour [65]. As in other AM technologies, new modifications to CODE are also appearing to improve the printing process, including new inks’ composition with high solids loading to subsequently reduce high shrinkages and enhance mechanical properties. As an example, Yang et al. 2019 [415] used carrageenan polymer (0.4 wt%) that absorbs water under heat-inducing, promoting rapid curing of alumina suspensions. During the 3D printing process, a hot silicone oil bath (65 °C) heats the extruded paste uniformly to promote fast solidification avoiding the collapse of the printed part, resulting in a component free of defects or deformations. Thin-wall alumina ceramics have been printed by this process, however, there was no report on the mechanical properties of the sintered pieces. Finally, the FFF technology was represented in the database with much fewer entries (9 entries) and, although not shown in Table 7 as a single category, the literature results deserve a comment. The FFF entries come from 3 papers published in 2020 [138,416,417] dedicated to the fabrication of alumina or zirconia parts, and reporting the mechanical properties of the sintered parts or, at least, relative density. Orlovská et al. 2020 [416] studied the influence of the layer thickness on the final properties of alumina ceramics obtained by FFF from a composite filament containing 50 vol% of ceramic powder. Depending on the layer thickness, RD ranged between 80-89 % and FS between 200-300 MPa after sintering at 1600 °C during 1 h holding time. Gorjan et al. [417] considered the rheological properties and printability of thermoplastic Al2O3 filaments and evaluated the flow behaviour of this feedstock by printing a model piece with thin walls. Although the printed sample presented a quite high RD value (around 99 %), low mechanical strength (around 150 MPa) was reported, emphasizing that the high density attained derives from the easiness to remove binders in thin-walled parts. The printing defects were however referred to as the primary cause that determined the low strength of the sintered samples. Cano et al. [138] studied the influence of infill orientation on the properties of zirconia parts fabricated by FFF. Three common defects in FFF shaping have been acknowledged as the main determinant for different densities (95-98 %) and bending strengths (366-512 MPa) values, namely inter-filament holes, defects created by the material over extrusion and nozzle shearing in the deposited material. As future research aiming the minimization of printing defects, the authors suggest the use of filaments with tight dimensional tolerances, control the over extrusion and evaluate the influence of the ceramic powder content and the moisture on the degradation of the organic components. The high amounts of organics (used as the base matrix in the production of filaments) require long thermal cycles for de-binding processes in parts produced by FFF, leading to high shrinkages in sintered parts, which is also appointed as a limitation for ceramics fabrication by this technology [418]. This table is organized by category and its technologies, following the same colour scheme as in Fig. 7. The results for each category/technology include all database entries referring to it. Some technologies are not in this representation (BJP, LSD, S-SLS, IJP, PSD, LCM and RC + FFF). 5 Challenges and future perspectives in the fabrication of dense ceramics This section focuses on four main topics. The first topic includes a historical evolution of the production processes aiming at alumina/zirconia technical ceramics (CPP, CCT and AM), while the second topic details and discusses the results obtained for the several AM categories and technologies. The discussion is supported by the dataset information and intends to provide an overall picture of the research over the last two decades. The third topic presents and discusses AM market trends, based on the quantitative information available on AM of functional ceramics. The previous discussions culminate in the fourth topic, which presents future trends and needs in the development of AM as well as in its implementation as a consolidated industrial process. 5.1 Historical evolution of the research in alumina/zirconia ceramics The recent interest in AM of functional ceramics has driven the development of numerous feedstocks and procedures predominantly still in R&D phases. The historical research panorama throughout the last 20 years in the fabrication of alumina, zirconia, ATZ and ZTA composites by traditional production processes (CPP and CCT) and AM is presented in Fig. 9 . As expected, AM exploitation in these ceramics increased significantly in the last 5 years, with a remarkable higher number of published papers in 2015-2020 for AM when compared to CPP and CCT. Both conventional processes have been losing some attention in the research field, clearly due to their maturity in the production of functional ceramics. A similar trend is observed for the number of database entries collected for AM entries, although the relative difference between AM and CPP/CCT entries is not so accentuated. This lower relative difference (within entries) can be explained by the fact that papers reporting AM results (powder- or suspension-based) also include the comparison to the structural and mechanical results attained by the closest-fitting conventional technologies. This is a clear indication that conventional processes are being used as a reference (gold standard) for AM evolution. Furthermore, the data are in good agreement with the conclusions and perspectives outlined by Franks et al. 2017 [8], forecasting research at multiple fronts related to colloidal-based science to further advance the AM research field, namely suspension-based AM categories. Solely in 2020, more than 40 research papers were dedicated to AM of dense alumina, zirconia and respective composites including their structural and mechanical characterization. Following this trend, an exponential growth in R&D of dense functional ceramics by AM is expected in the next 5 years. Since alumina or zirconia ceramics are now highly explored in AM research field, further market exploitation will certainly occur for several applications, including biomedical ones. On the other hand, considering the few manuscripts devoted to AM of ZTA or ATZ ceramics published until now (see Table 6), a clear opportunity for R&D in these materials is identified. The AM scientific evolution throughout time illustrated in Fig. 9 agrees with the patenting scenario of ceramics AM recently reported by Mathews et al. 2020 [419]. The number of patent registrations from 2008 to 2014 has been slower and gradually increasing, with a sudden growth from 2015-2018 and the highest number of registrations being reached in 2017. According to the authors, the number of patents reported in 2018 underestimates its real number (as patents are only available in the public domain after their publication, on average, 18 months from the filing date) and continuous exponential growth is foreseen in the incoming years (data source PatSeer Pro™). The abrupt increasing trend of patent applications in the short-term is also supported by the data reported by the European Patent Office [420]. The patents on ceramics published between 2008 and 2018 reached the total number of 1110 [419,420], distributed among those aiming the development of material formulations for AM technologies (421 patents), focusing the novelties in processes (345), dedicated to the new applications for ceramic parts produced by AM (189) and dealing with equipment advances (155). Concerning applications, the healthcare sector was the largest one from a patent viewpoint, with other industries gaining some space, such as aerospace and automobiles, mechanical and metallurgical and electronics and electrical, from which zirconia, alumina and their composites will be strongly contributing [419,420]. Finally, in terms of geographic distribution, the Asian continent was identified as the leader in registering novelties in AM of ceramics, with China being the key player. This agrees with the distribution of the AM database entries by country displayed in Fig. 10 , showing that more than 50 % of the AM database entries (out of 359, Table 2) have the participation of, at least, one R&D institution from China. This number goes to 17 % (out of 954 entries, Table 2) for the database entries related to conventional technologies. 5.2 Selection criteria for AM technologies in their production Fig. 11 presents the distribution of AM database entries per category and technology distinguishing alumina, zirconia and their composites. As expected, VP is the AM category most explored for all materials, given the advantages outlined in Table 5 and market ranking for SLA/DLP and LCM technologies. Even if the higher amounts of resins could lead to cracks and deformations on the produced materials, the drawbacks of VP are overcome using slow rates and longer holding stages in the binder burnout step. Additionally, photopolymerizable resin-based alumina and zirconia suspensions are already available in the market (e.g. from Lithoz [345]) opening the possibility for the research community to be highly focused on the fine-tuning of the printing process and sintering conditions of the green ceramic parts to achieve optimal final properties. For alumina and zirconia dense ceramics, ME and PBF have been the second most explored categories (Fig. 11). The increased number of ME experiments (namely for RC and CODE) is explained by the fact that these suspension-based technologies make use of small amounts of organics when compared with VP, for example. Furthermore, since both alumina and zirconia ceramics were deeply studied in CCT, it is expected that, at least, part of the knowledge acquired in CCT could be directly applied to AM. As a matter of fact, RC is well-established in the literature to produce porous components and current R&D points out that RC is also well-suited to print dense bodies. The preference for the PBF category could be related to the easiness of use and process rate (powder-based SLS) and the possibility to print the final ceramic part in a single-step (SLM). Following the same principle (ease and speed of printing), BJ has also been applied to high-quality technical ceramics, even if showing a small number of database entries (around 10 % for alumina or zirconia and no entries for mixtures) perhaps related to the low density of the green parts produced by BJ technologies. Although much less explored than alumina or zirconia ceramics, the alumina-zirconia composites produced by AM technologies are becoming a vivid topic of research, based on the growing interest of these ceramics in the healthcare sector (dentistry and orthopaedics). The high applicability and acceptance of AM of zirconia in this sector also explain its higher maturity R&D level when compared to alumina, concerning final density and mechanical performance (see Fig. 8). Surprisingly, LENS from the DED category is the second most explored technology in the fabrication of composites, oppositely to alumina or zirconia (see Fig. 11). This could be explained by the existence of a eutectic mixture in the system alumina/zirconia arising the interest of the scientific community to explore these composite materials using direct technologies (single-step) such as LENS and SLM. 5.3 Market trends in AM of ceramics According to the Additive Manufacturing Landscape from the 2020 report published by AMFG/Autonomous manufacturing (www.amfg.ai), the most pronounced market categories are hardware, materials and services [421]. As illustrated in Fig. 12 , hardware represents 56 % of the total AM market and includes 3D printing machines (metal, polymer, ceramic, composite) as main segments, as well as desktop and electronic machines. Materials hold 20 % of the market share, divided between metals and polymers with no reference to ceramic materials (residual market share). The remaining 23 % of the market share includes AM services comprising software, research institutions and post-processing. Currently, metal and polymer 3D printing machines and corresponding materials are the largest market segments. Nevertheless, just a few practical full-scale applications for 3D-printed ceramics are available on the market, especially for structural applications. As an example, Tofail et al. 2028 [9] refer to key AM applications in several industries e.g. automobile, aerospace/aeronautics, medicine/pharmaceutical, sports and construction. The numbers presented in Fig. 12 give clear evidence that AM is not yet fully established in the production of ceramics at the industrial level which in turn could be understood as a strong opportunity for research, innovation and new business niche [9]. This market landscape is in agreement with the trend of patents for AM of ceramics [419,421]. As most of the patents in materials (2015-2017) are registered by R&D Institutions, the knowledge is currently protected and available to be either acquired by the AM industry or on the public domain, in the next few years [419]. The research to market time increases by the protection of the intellectual property and delays the market growth for the given period of the protection. Concordantly, the number of patent registrations on hardware (equipment and machinery) is lower than that on materials [421], which can explain why ceramic hardware currently holds a market share of 7 % against no market share reported for ceramic materials (Fig. 12). Certainly, the evolution of ceramic AM hardware and their fast introduction in the market roadmap leveraged from the previous (and already consolidated) knowledge acquired in the development of hardware for metals and polymers. Currently, the best-known companies that develop 3D printers to process ceramic materials include WASP (Italy), AIM3D (Germany) and Nanoe (France) for material extrusion, ADMATEC (Netherlands), Prodways (France), Steinbach AG (Germany), 3DCeram (France), Lithoz (Austria) for vat photopolymerization, ExOne (USA), XJet (Israel) and Voxeljet (Germany) for binder jetting and material jetting. However, as the demand for AM of ceramic components is growing, the development of new and/or updated hardware as well as adequate materials will inevitably become the future key segments in this area. The AM technology applied to ceramics is foreseen to reach maturity within the next five/six years when AM of advanced ceramics (like alumina, zirconia and their composites) are expected to drive the growth of the ceramic 3D printing market in the medium to long term [421]. In this market report, ME is established as a typical technology for clay-like materials, while VP, BJ and MJ are presented as more suitable for high-performance ceramic materials. However, the large number of published research papers/experiments in ME technologies in recent years (Fig. 9) supports a paradigm change in the near future, in which ME technologies could be industrialized for technical ceramics. Several economic reports on ceramics AM include projections of revenues for the AM technologies implemented in ceramics processing. As an example, recent SmarTech reports revealed that the revenues in AM of ceramics are in a fast-upward trend and are expected to generate a global market segment of approximately $3.8 billion in 2029 [422]. As illustrated in Fig. 13a, the market in 2020 totalizes $268 million and has its highest revenue on services and hardware (totalizing 2/3 of the total market, around 1/3 for each segment) followed by materials and parts segments (totalizing 1/3 of the total market, around 13 % and 20 % respectively for each segment). Until 2028, these market segments will grow consistently, although at different rhythms: i) the segment addressing the production of parts is expected to hold the largest development (around 34 times the 2020 market value), leveraged from the acquired experience of those working with AM techniques for metal and polymer materials; ii) materials and hardware segments are expected to uprise similarly and more moderately until 2028 (~10 times the 2020 market value); iii) services segment is foreseen in 2028 to hold the lowest market increase with respect to 2020 (~5 times the 2020 market value). Therefore, a clear market shift is foreseen for 2028, where the development of materials and parts will be the highest revenue segments (totalizing 60 % of the total market) against services and hardware (40 %). As a general overview over the incoming years, the logistic processes in the AM sector are expected to be converted in commercial manufacturing, in which both processes and materials will be more intensively and continuously explored, validated and implemented to accomplish the necessary improvements in the ceramic materials and parts produced by AM. That effect will be particularly visible after 2025, the changing point in the increasing trend of the forecasts when the major ceramics AM technologies are expected to be ready to support actual serial production [422]. Another report presents the revenue projections for the ceramic AM market (2019-2029), distinguishing different ceramic materials [423]. Fig. 13b shows an exponential increase in ceramic AM materials revenues predicted for the next decade. Furthermore, technical ceramics currently hold and will continue to hold, larger revenues in comparison with traditional ceramics (around 84 % of total revenues in 2020 and ~70 % of total revenues in 2029). Although exhibiting lower revenues, traditional materials (including sand, cement and glass) increase their revenue share in 2029 (16 % in 2020 against 30 % in 2029). These materials are known to be extremely versatile and affordable end-use materials, ideal for a wide range of utilitarian products as well as industrial moulds [423]. Among the technical ceramics, zirconia stands out as the leading in revenues, in 2020 and 2029, maintaining a 38 % share of the total revenues. Together, alumina- and zirconia-based materials will hold, in 2029, around 52 % of the revenues against other technical and traditional materials. These market perspectives are clearly supported by the current research activity and emphasis regarding alumina and zirconia ceramics (see Fig. 11). The current research efforts in AM of these materials will sustain the implementation of reliable technologies for dense functional ceramics that are expected, in a near future, to be translated to the market. Since the above-mentioned market reports have been released before the COVID-19 pandemic situation, significant changes are expected in the increasing trend of the market forecasts. For 2020, the global smart manufacturing market size (which may include AM of functional ceramics) is already estimated to decrease around 16 % when compared to the pre-COVID-19 evaluation [424]. Also, during several months in 2020 and 2021, manufacturing units were forced to close without the possibility to continue their production, which created a ripple effect throughout the world’s manufacturing facilities and, inclusive, ruptured the entire supply chain [424]. However, it should be highlighted that additive manufacturing also emerged in this pandemic period as a strong solution to fight the lack of several devices and support the shortage in personal protective equipment for the medical staff and general community [425,426]. Therefore, feed by the urgent need of the situation, a larger investment in production processes may take place with the aim to reduce the time-to-market of the critical devices and equipment to cope with COVID-19 impacts. The unexpected extra-investment may leverage further AM developments and will allow its materials and processes currently under R&D to escalate more rapidly to the industry. 5.4 Future research trends, industrialization and needs Additive manufacturing of functional ceramics still needs to overcome the limited performances of the printed parts, including density, mechanical properties, surface finish, geometrical complexity and scalability. Although significant research efforts have been made to attain dense alumina, zirconia and their composites, the widespread of this knowledge at the industrial level still demands additional experimental work and strong investments. Even if AM technologies are currently able to produce small alumina/zirconia components with acceptable properties, at a lab scale and even some at the industrial level, there is still no demonstration concerning the successful AM production of large bulk 3D-printed parts with high density and smooth surface. Therefore, the AM establishment in the industrial production of large bulk parts depends mostly on the development and the maturation of the AM processes to allow the production of AM parts and components with performance, at least, comparable to that of parts and components fabricated by conventional manufacturing (CPP and CCT). Based on the extensive knowledge already gathered with conventional processing of alumina or zirconia ceramics and, given the large impact of particle size distribution and particle packing in the final densities and structural performances of the ceramics, colloidal-based AM technologies stand out as the most promising for the production of these ceramics. The use of a liquid medium in colloidal processing allows a better dispersion and high homogeneity of submicron/nanopowders, resulting in a more effective packing density and higher sintering activity than coarser ceramic particles. The chance to use small-sized particles opens up the possibility of using lower tip sizes, e.g. in ME technologies, which enables the formation of thinner layers and improvements in surface roughness. The knowledge of colloidal processing will also help in the preparation of long-term stable inks/pastes to be stored, which will allow expanding the market of slurry-based technologies, especially those from the ME category. Regarding the materials and considering the current research and industrial status on VP, DED and PBF technologies for alumina or zirconia ceramics, it is foreseen that both ATZ and ZTA ceramic composites will be vastly explored in a near future and will soon appear in the market. This is in good agreement with Mathews et al. 2020 [419] when pointing out that innovations in ceramic-based composite materials suitable for AM are on the rise owing to their adaptability, suitability and mechanical properties. Therefore, a significant development in the AM ceramics sector is expected in the next few years, namely in processes, materials, and applications. The sintering process is identified as the largest obstacle in ceramic AM processing, stated in high thermal stresses generated (e.g. in direct technologies as LENS and SLM), high energy consumption, long heating cycles (de-binding and sintering) and environmental contaminations (high carbon footprint). The cold sintering process (CSP) has been suggested as an alternative solution that could reinvent the concept of sintering and, thus, shift the processing paradigm in ceramics [427,428]. Although highly explored in other technical ceramics, CSP has also been reported in the fabrication of zirconia stabilized with 8 mol% yttria [429] as a good mark for future progress. Therefore, it is expected that CSP could be integrated within existing AM technologies [430], including printing processes, providing a significant breakthrough in establishing greener manufacturing routes, and concomitantly opening the door for new materials and applications. Multi-material AM in the same piece could be a reality if the sintering process is simplified. Also, the consequences and impacts of adopting AM production on ceramics industrial sustainability (i.e. circular economy, recycling and life cycle assessment) are current concerns [431,432]. For some organizations, AM will be a direct replacement in the production chain while, for others, AM will be complementary to the existing conventional production. Other organizations will try to enter the market with small-scale customized products, produced and sold at a more competitive price since AM can decrease production costs. Concerning the type of materials and sustainability of the AM processes, ceramics are pointed out as the class of materials in need of more research (namely in energy and costs optimization, use of environmentally friendly materials and processes), as well as in need of increasing the potential for recycling. R&D priorities in line with sustainability requirements include automating and minimizing post-processing of ceramics after production, continuing to lower-cost equipment and materials, and increasing diversification of machine sizes, speeds and accuracies and reduce toxic additives in the feedstock. Five insights on the future of technical ceramics have also been captured at Ceramics Expo 2019 (a leading annual conference and forum for the advanced ceramics and glass industries held in Cleveland, Ohio, US), specifically: (1) the need for ceramics in 5G, (2) growing industry partnerships, (3) improving knowledge in AM, (4) need for speed in R&D and (5) ceramics customization allowable by AM. 5G antenna performance will require materials to handle thermal management of the complex operating environments associated with 5G infrastructure; in this context, technical ceramic materials have unparalleled properties. The demand for small ceramic parts with tight tolerances will drive the AM industry to fill this gap. The market trends will subsequently generate partnerships between industry and research institutions that, in turn, will speed up the R&D in this area. This trend is somewhat highly perceptible nowadays and is supported by the data collected in this paper (Fig. 9). Furthermore, it is worthwhile to refer that the ceramics AM industry faces hiring challenges, concerning AM specialized individuals that could help to drive the industry forward. Therefore, raising a talent pipeline of leaders, engineers and machine workers in AM of ceramics is a future need, in which educational institutions, and namely the universities, will contribute by offering specialized AM courses. When all these conditions are met, AM of ceramics will move from a research and prototyping attempt into full-scale design and manufacturing of customized components and composites. AM of alumina- and zirconia-based functional ceramics have the potential to revolutionize the industry with the possibility to decline traditional manufacturing for certain applications, even though the knowledge acquired in CPP and CCT technologies are still playing an important role during this changing stage. 6 Conclusions In the last 20 years of research, conventional powder pressing and colloidal-based technologies achieved a high degree of maturity in the knowhow of the interdependences between processing variables and final performance of functional ceramics, as those based on alumina, zirconia and their composites. Particles packing, particle size and size distribution, particles’ homogeneity, solids loading, suspensions stability, sintering temperature and time are examples of important factors that determine the final properties of the ceramics. Densification associated with geometric complexity fabrication is easier to accomplish in traditional colloidal-based than in powder-based technologies. The reasons for that are also feeding the suspension-based AM technologies (such as SLA/DLP/LCM, Robocasting, CODE, MJ) and driven the conception of new technologies (LSD as suspension-based BJ and S-iLS as suspension-based indirect laser sintering) from categories where the feedstock has been typically a powder.
