Also, the fabrication of high-density (pore-free) and cracks-free technical ceramic parts with high surface finishing by colloidal-based processes explains the research emphasis on research towards suspension-based AM technologies. Furthermore, the continuous proposal of new AM technologies for ceramic materials in recent years, or even variants of existing technologies well established for other materials (e.g. polymers or metals) has led to novel and diverse terminologies in the literature reports. Therefore, the standardization of the names (and definitions) in ceramic technologies with similar processing principles is identified as a need. Being AM well-suited to low-volume production and complex-shaped ceramic components, research in AM of technical ceramics has begun to replace traditional processing. Nevertheless, conventional processing will always prevail for mass production at lower manufacturing costs, regardless of the attained final properties. AM is showing a rapid increase in research literature reports in the last 3 years, being zirconia more studied than alumina (or the ZTA and ATZ composites). In fact, the strength and toughness improvements in zirconia-based ceramics are still current challenges in conventional processing and subsequently in additive manufacturing, since this property promotes significantly its industrial application. Zirconia phases composition and phase stabilizers, grain size and sintering methods are still current research topics in the search for the best performance of zirconia. The widespread use of zirconia AM parts in the healthcare market well justifies the higher maturity level found for this material. Nevertheless, mechanical properties comparable to those obtained by conventional processes have been reported in several AM studies, for all materials. The VP and ME technologies are those leading to better densification and consequently smaller standard deviations on the resulting structural performances among different reports. The results achieved by BJ, MJ and PBF are still far from the required for certain applications. The use of single-step technologies to produce defect-free and fully dense alumina or zirconia ceramic parts is not yet a reality and seems to be far from being achievable shortly, as just a few research studies have been reported on this topic. When compared to pure alumina or stabilized zirconia ceramics, Al2O3-ZrO2 composites are less studied in conventional processing as well as in AM. The eutectic composition in this Al2O3-ZrO2 system started to motivate the fabrication of these materials by direct consolidation techniques as LENS (DED) and SLM (PBF), oppositely to alumina or zirconia. So, the R&D in AM of these composite materials is still in its infancy which turns to be an opportunity to create business and expand the market in materials/processes in AM ceramics. The interest in AM of functional ceramics is growing rapidly while industrial adoption is not keeping this pace, but slowly increasing, being still required strong efforts to place new materials, processes and new machines in the market, that goes through more R&D, new applications for ceramics produced by AM, creation of industrial partnerships and improving knowledge in the employers of AM industries. doc_title: Dynamic PCA Based Statistical Monitoring of Air Pollutant Concentrations in Wildfire Scenarios
doc_abstract: © 2022, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.In 2021 the media reported multiple scenarios of devastation due to wildfires throughout the Mediterranean Basin. Wildfires have short- and long-term impacts on air quality due to the substantial release of air pollutants that can spread over large distances and may constitute a threat to human health. In this context, it is widely beneficial to develop suitable methods for continuous monitoring of air pollutants, able to produce quantitative time-variant snapshots of air quality. This work borrows some ideas of Statistical Process Monitoring (SPM) based on Dynamic Principal Component Analysis (DPCA). Shortly, the multivariate collected data are condensed into time-variant evaluations of the Hotelling’s T2 and Q statistics, which allow the quantification of the deviance of the process with respect to a reference behavior. The aim of this method is the identification of temporal episodes of large deviations from typical (generally safe) levels of concentrations. The analysis focuses on hourly time series of CO and PM concentrations, collected during 2021 at a monitoring station located in the populated area of Athens (Greece). Despite some methodological limitations and the reduced sample size, DPCA based SPM provides a promising framework to identify temporal episodes of large deviations from typical levels of air pollutants.

doc_title: Influence of filament patterning in structural properties of dense alumina ceramics printed by robocasting
doc_abstract: © 2021 The Society of Manufacturing EngineersRobocasting is an extrusion-based additive manufacturing (AM) technique, highly explored in the fabrication of porous structures or thin-walled ceramics. Comparing to other slurry-based AM technologies, robocasting presents a high potential to produce dense bulk ceramics, thanks to the low organic binder contents and high solids loading used in the feedstock. Despite these benefits, the robocasting fabrication of ceramics with similar mechanical performance as those produced by traditional methods remains a challenge. The goal of this work is to fine-tune the robocasting printing process of dense alumina ceramics by evaluating the influence of in-fill filaments orientation and the medium where the deposition process occurs (air or paraffin bath), on defects and mechanical performance of the sintered parts. Relative density, shrinkage, three-point flexural strength, Young's modulus and hardness were analysed. The specimens with the highest performance were sintered at 1550 °C or 1600 °C temperatures for 2 h holding time and the results were compared with slip casting (SC) samples sintered in the same conditions. Alumina robocasting samples, printed longitudinally in air with controlled humidity and sintered at 1600 °C, exhibited relative density ≈99% with flexural strength (≈350 MPa), Young's modulus (≈366 GPa) and hardness (≈17 GPa) values comparable to those obtained for SC samples. Numerical modelling and simulation were used to analyse the experimental values and the anisotropic behaviour of the printed specimens. Experimental Young's modulus results were compared with the Voigt-Reuss bound and the Hashin-Shtrikman upper-bound, as well as the analytical predictions of a Mooney-type exponential relation.

Olhero a ⁎ a CICECO – Aveiro Institute of Materials, Department of Materials and Ceramic Engineering, University of Aveiro, Portugal CICECO – Aveiro Institute of Materials Department of Materials and Ceramic Engineering University of Aveiro Portugal CICECO – Aveiro Institute of Materials, Department of Materials and Ceramic Engineering, University of Aveiro, Portugal b TEMA – Centre for Mechanical Technology and Automation, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Aveiro, Portugal TEMA – Centre for Mechanical Technology and Automation Department of Mechanical Engineering University of Aveiro Portugal TEMA – Centre for Mechanical Technology and Automation, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Aveiro, Portugal c IEETA – Institute of Electronics and Informatics Engineering of Aveiro, Department of Electronics, Telecommunications and Informatics, University of Aveiro, Portugal IEETA – Institute of Electronics and Informatics Engineering of Aveiro Department of Electronics, Telecommunications and Informatics University of Aveiro Portugal IEETA – Institute of Electronics and Informatics Engineering of Aveiro and CIDMA – Centre for Research & Development in Mathematics and Applications, University of Aveiro, Portugal ⁎ Corresponding author. Robocasting is an extrusion-based additive manufacturing (AM) technique, highly explored in the fabrication of porous structures or thin-walled ceramics. Comparing to other slurry-based AM technologies, robocasting presents a high potential to produce dense bulk ceramics, thanks to the low organic binder contents and high solids loading used in the feedstock. Despite these benefits, the robocasting fabrication of ceramics with similar mechanical performance as those produced by traditional methods remains a challenge. The goal of this work is to fine-tune the robocasting printing process of dense alumina ceramics by evaluating the influence of in-fill filaments orientation and the medium where the deposition process occurs (air or paraffin bath), on defects and mechanical performance of the sintered parts. Relative density, shrinkage, three-point flexural strength, Young's modulus and hardness were analysed. The specimens with the highest performance were sintered at 1550 °C or 1600 °C temperatures for 2 h holding time and the results were compared with slip casting (SC) samples sintered in the same conditions. Alumina robocasting samples, printed longitudinally in air with controlled humidity and sintered at 1600 °C, exhibited relative density ≈99% with flexural strength (≈350 MPa), Young's modulus (≈366 GPa) and hardness (≈17 GPa) values comparable to those obtained for SC samples. Numerical modelling and simulation were used to analyse the experimental values and the anisotropic behaviour of the printed specimens. Experimental Young's modulus results were compared with the Voigt-Reuss bound and the Hashin-Shtrikman upper-bound, as well as the analytical predictions of a Mooney-type exponential relation. Keywords Robocasting Alumina Dense ceramics Mechanical properties Filaments patterning Finite element analysis Representative Unit-Cell Micromechanical models 1 Introduction The manufacturing industry has been moving towards customization instead of mass production of single-use products for several reasons: (i) the increase in economic competitiveness, (ii) the possibility to better meet individual customer needs and (iii) to reduce wastes and costs towards a more sustainable economy [1]. Additive Manufacturing (AM) plays an important role in this path, providing flexibility to produce complex designs, usually at a reduced cost (time and material) [2,3]. Although AM is well-established for polymers and metals, at scientific and industrial levels, AM of ceramics has been recently growing [4,5]. The inherent properties of ceramic materials and their processing conditions (high melting point and the need for thermal treatment for consolidation after shaping) might be some of the difficulties in the development of efficient AM processes for these materials. Therefore, the production of defect-free AM ceramic parts with proper mechanical performance is a current research challenge in the ceramics' field [5,6]. Alumina is a ceramic material widely used in the production of technical ceramics for high-performance applications (a.k.a. high-performance ceramics, HPC [6]), including supports for catalysts, and thermal or electrical insulators. The manufacture of these HPC components requires strict quality control, including high density (>99% of relative density) and tight limits in dimensions, structural and mechanical properties after sintering, being up to now widely fabricated by conventional ceramic shaping techniques, namely, powder (pressing) or colloidal-based (slip casting, gel casting, injection moulding) [7–11]. Although final ceramic parts with high structural performance can be produced by conventional methods, it is unlikely that these methods will be suitable for the fabrication of certain geometries to answer the up-to-date technological evolutions. In particular, the powder-based techniques, typically involving uniaxial pressing followed by cold isostatic pressing and singular sintering conditions (e.g., hot isostatic pressing) to attain high dense ceramics, are limited to simple geometries. The production of complex shapes by powder-based techniques demands hard machining to achieve the final shape, which is a high-cost and time-consuming process that discards valuable material and wears cutting tools [12]. Colloidal-based techniques, such as near-net-shape slip casting and gel casting, overcome some of these disadvantages and thus are highly recommended for complex ceramic architectures, even if requiring a master and respective mould forming [7,9,11]. Particles' segregation, moulds complexity and difficulties to achieve dense massive pieces are disadvantages of slip casting, while toxicity associated with organic gel precursors and porosity after sintering derived to their burn-out are weaknesses of gel casting. Thus, AM appeared as a potential alternative for HPC [4,5,13]. The AM techniques vastly proposed for ceramics, particularly for the production of alumina parts, include selective laser melting/sintering (SLM/SLS) [14,15], binder jetting [16,17], robocasting [18–23], fused filament fabrication (FFF) [24], stereolithography (SLA) and digital light processing (DLP) [25,26]. Due to the nature of the process (mainly powder as feedstock material), SLS/SLM and binder jetting usually result in highly porous ceramic parts while suspension-based AM technologies from material extrusion (robocasting/Ceramic On-Demand Extrusion (CODE)) and vat photopolymerization (SLA/DLP) categories are more suitable for the production of dense ceramics [13,23,27]. Therefore, most of these suspension-based AM processes demand the addition of organic additives (binder, resins) as a base matrix for the ceramic particles, being compulsory the use of a binder burnout process and a sintering step to densify the final structure after printing. The content of these additives is particularly high in FFF, SLA and DLP, requiring extended thermal debinding to avoid cracks and high porosity levels, resulting in high shrinkage. Robocasting is a viable alternative that requires low organic binder contents when compared to FFF, SLA and DLP, being considered an affordable and reliable technique for ceramics fabrication [18]. Being an extrusion-based technique, it relies on a viscous paste with suitable rheological properties to flow from a small orifice, keeping its shape afterwards. Although robocasting is well established in the fabrication of porous structures for several ceramic materials and applications [4,5,27–31], it has just started to be explored for dense ceramic structures [32,33], showing just a few publications for alumina [27,34]. Feilden et al. [20] developed hydrogel-based alumina inks with 36 vol% of solids to print simple dense 3D parts by robocasting. The authors concluded that the mechanical strength is directly related to the defects resulting from the printing process, as well as to the orientation of the part concerning the printing direction. Low amounts of ceramic solids, which could lead to high shrinkage and fast and non-uniform drying during the printing process, were also identified to reduce ceramics structural performance [4,5]. Rueschhoff et al. [23] maximized solids' amount of alumina inks to 53–56 vol% and, although relative densities above 98% were obtained, the authors concluded that the flexural strength (ranging from 134 to 157 MPa) was not influenced by the solid loading (in the range considered). To avoid defects arising from the drying process, a new variant of robocasting referred to as CODE, has been developed [35]. In this technique, the ceramic paste is extruded inside a paraffin bath container, one layer is printed and infrared radiation is applied to dry it uniformly. Although fast water evaporation is prevented in the ceramic part during printing, other complications are envisioned during the sintering step due to the presence of the organic components (paraffin/oil bath), which can be minimized with the use of pastes/suspensions with high solids loading. As an example, Ghazanfari et al. [36] used CODE to obtain alumina specimens from suspensions holding 60 vol% of solids. The samples presented a relative density of 98% and an average flexural strength of 364 ± 50 MPa. In summary, even though a few recent strategies have been reported to reach high dense ceramics, the ability to also reach proper mechanical properties from high reproducibility methods remains a challenge and demands further scientific efforts to fine-tune materials and processes in the fabrication of high-performance ceramics. Aiming the definition of the optimal conditions to produce advanced alumina ceramics by robocasting, the present work evaluates the effect of printing strategies, namely infill orientation of filaments (different patterns), printing environment (paraffin bath or in air with controlled humidity) and sintering temperature on the structural and mechanical properties of dense alumina parts. Shrinkage, density, flexural strength, hardness and Young's modulus of sintered alumina samples were quantified and compared to those obtained in alumina samples fabricated by slip casting, a colloidal-based manufacturing technique. The quantitative experimental values of all alumina samples were analysed together with microstructure and compared with the numerical values obtained by finite element analyses. Both experimental and numerical results for Young's modulus were compared with the bound of Voigt-Reuss and the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman, as well as with the analytical predictions of a Mooney-type exponential relation. 2 Materials and methods This section describes the experimental procedure, including the samples preparation and their characterisation, as well as the methods used in numerical modelling and simulation. 2.1 Suspensions and inks preparation process and characterisation An aqueous suspension of a submicron Al2O3 powder (CT3000-SG, Amaltis GmbH, Ludwigshafen, Germany), with an average particle size of D50 = 0.35 μm and 50 vol% of solids, was initially prepared by dispersing the powder in deionized water in presence of 1 wt% (based on the alumina solids amount) of Dolapix CE64 (Zimmer and Schwartz, Germany) [11]. The suspension was deagglomerated in a ball milling with alumina spheres (spheres to powder ratio of 3:1) for 24 h. This feedstock suspension was directly used to prepare alumina samples by slip casting (for comparison purposes) or after fine-tuned to obtain a proper ink for robocasting. For the ink preparation, 0.5 wt% (based on alumina solids amount) of carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC, 250 000 Mw, Colorobbia, Portugal) were used as a thickening agent of the suspension. This binder-assisted suspension was homogenized for 5 min at 800 rpm in a planetary centrifugal mixer (ARE-250, Thinky Co., Tokyo, Japan). Finally, different amounts of polyethyleneimine solution (PEI, Sigma-Aldrich, USA, Mn ~1800 and Mw ~2000), namely 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 wt%, were added to obtain extrudable inks with adequate stiffness. The final paste was mixed and degassed using again the planetary centrifugal mixer for an additional 5 min at 1000 rpm velocity to ensure high homogeneity. Suspension and inks were characterized by rheological properties using a rotational rheometer (Kinexus Pro+, Malvern, UK) at 25 °C, holding a solvent trap to prevent samples drying during experiments. The shear viscosity was measured using a cone/plate system (4°/40 mm) with a gap of 150 μm in the shear rate range of 0.1 to 600 s−1. Final alumina-based inks were characterized by amplitude sweep measurements at 1 Hz frequency in oscillatory mode, using a plate sensor (Φ = 20 mm), with a 1 mm gap size. 2.2 Alumina samples preparation by robocasting and slip casting A robocasting system (Model EBRD-A32, 3D Inks, LLC, USA) was used to print prismatic alumina bars with the as-prepared ink as feedstock material. The ink was loaded into a 5 ml syringe (Nordson, USA) and extruded through a nozzle with an internal diameter of 0.41 mm with 10 mm/s printing speed. The alumina specimens were constructed on a smooth alumina substrate. Two different printing conditions were used, both at room temperature, to ensure uniform drying during printing: (i) immersed in a low viscosity liquid paraffin (Benzina Química Internacional, Portugal) and (ii) in air within a high humidity level (around 85% relative humidity, RH). After printing, the alumina structures were dried at room temperature with controlled humidity for 24 h and then at 100 °C in an oven for 24 h. 3D models with different printing filament orientations were designed in RoboCAD software and then exported to G-code format. Suitable dimensions were used in the CAD models to attain standardized testing bars after sintering for mechanical properties with approximately 45 × 4 × 3 mm3 (length × height × width) [37]. Fig. 1 shows the CAD model of the three different printing configurations used in the production of the rectangular samples. Solid cast bars were also obtained by conventional slip casting in suitable plaster moulds, using the as-prepared alumina slurries with 50 vol%. After the de-moulding step, the slip casting samples were dried following the same procedure used to dry the AM samples. 2.3 Sintering and characterisation of the alumina samples All prismatic Al2O3 bars were sintered at 1550 °C using the following schedule: 2 °C/min heating rate until 600 °C, with 1 h holding time at this temperature to burn out the organic components; 2 °C/min heating rate up to 1000 °C with 1 h holding time and finally, 5 °C/min from 1000 °C to final sintering temperature (1550 °C) with 2 h holding time, followed by cooling to room temperature. The alumina samples with configuration and printing environment condition that presented the best results when sintered at 1550 °C/2 h have been selected to be also tested at 1600 °C/2 h following the same heating schedule. For comparison, both sintering temperatures (1550 °C/2 h and 1600 °C/2 h) were also used in slip casting samples. Linear shrinkage was measured in green (after drying step) and sintered samples, while the bulk density of all sintered structures was measured by Archimedes immersion method and relative density calculated using 3.98 g·cm−3 as the reference value for alumina. The mechanical strength of the specimens was measured by three-point flexural tests in a universal testing machine (AG-IS 10 kN, Shimadzu Corpor., Kyoto, Japan) according to the ASTM C1161–18 standard [37]. Tests were carried out in the perpendicular direction to the printing plane of the 3D structures at a constant speed of 0.5 mm·min−1. At least 10 samples were tested for each composition and property (namely shrinkage, bulk density and flexural strength) to obtain more reliable results and to access the variability of the measurements. The Young's modulus was measured by the dynamic and non-destructive impulse excitation technique (IEP, Grindosonic MK5i system Belgium) from two replicas of each sample, on the top side of each sintered specimen. Vickers hardness of sintered alumina samples was measured using a small fragment that was mounted in epoxy and polished to an optical finish. At least 10 indentations were made in each sample with 2 kgf as indentation load using a microhardness tester (Wilson VH1102, BUEHLER) and DiaMet Template hardness testing software. Morphological features and microstructure of the samples' cross-section in the fracture surface were analysed by an optical microscope with a camera (LEICA EZ4HD, Germany) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S4100, Hitachi High-Technologies Europe, GmbH, Germany). 2.4 Numerical modelling and simulation Computer-Aided Design (CAD) and Engineering (CAE) strategies were applied to understand and discuss the mechanical performance shown by the different alumina samples printed by robocasting with different infill orientations (R-A1, R-A2 and R-A3), using SOLIDWORKS 2020. For all prismatic bars' design, the same basic parameters were used, namely filament diameter of 0.41 mm, horizontal spacing of 0.37 mm and vertical spacing of 0.37 mm. The external envelope was the same for all the samples (7.440 × 55.170 × 6.422 mm3). In sequence, CAD modelling was used to evaluate the spatial distribution of the material. Representative Unit-Cells (RUCs) were tested to obtain a numerical reference for the effective anisotropic behaviour while bending tests provided a glimpse of local effects in terms of stress levels and their influence in the performance evaluation of these brittle heterogeneous materials. These RUCs were tested using the Finite Element Method (FEM) from the properties of Alumina (Al2O3) considering linear elasticity, i.e., a base material with Young's modulus of 380 GPa and Poisson's coefficient of 0.22. Quadratic tetrahedral elements (10 nodes, 30 degrees of freedom) were used. Each configuration was evaluated with a tensile test for each one of the three axes, imposing a prescribed displacement on each direction. The remaining boundary conditions were the same for all tests, with symmetry conditions (sliders) over the three opposing planes to promote a result as close as possible to the uniaxial. Additionally, the experimental results obtained for Young's modulus of different alumina samples obtained by robocasting (R-A1, R-A2 and R-A3) and slip casting (SC), sintered at both temperatures (1550 °C and 1600 °C), were analysed using the bound of Voigt [38] and the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman [39,40]. Briefly, for a base material with Young's modulus E 0 and porosity ϕ, the (upper) bound of Voigt is given by [41]. (1) E V = E 0 1 − ϕ . The upper bounds of Hashin-Shtrikman for the shear modulus G and bulk modulus K are given from the correspondent properties of the base material, G 0 and K 0, and the porosity ϕ, respectively by [41]. (2) G H S + = G 0 + − 1 G 0 + 1 − ϕ 6 K 0 + 2 G 0 5 G 0 3 K 0 + 4 G 0 − 1 ϕ and (3) K HS + = K 0 + − 1 K 0 + 1 − ϕ 3 3 K 0 + 4 G 0 − 1 ϕ . Based on these relations, it is possible to obtain an approximation for the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman for Young's modulus as (4) E HS + = 9 K HS + G HS + 3 K HS + + G HS + . Finally, the Mooney-type exponential relation [42] defined as (5) E PG = E 0 exp − 2 ϕ 1 − ϕ , is another prediction model for the relation of Young's modulus with porosity which corresponds to a semiempirical extension of the dilute approximations and allows modelling the non-linear dependence between these variables. Further information and a critical assessment of the model relations describing the porosity dependence on Young's modulus can be consulted in [43]. 3 Results This section starts with the presentation of the experimental results, including the characterisation of the inks followed by the description of the structural properties of alumina bars. Finally, the experimental results are compared with those obtained by numerical modelling and simulation. 3.1 Inks characterisation Robocasting imposes stringent requirements on the rheological behaviour of the pastes, being mandatory a trade-off between an easy flow through a narrow nozzle (small opening) and shape retention immediately after printing. Different strategies can be used for tailoring this type of rheological behaviour in ceramic suspensions, including: (i) gelation/thickening mechanisms during/after printing or (ii) producing the inks with desirable rheological behaviour before printing [28,44]. In the present work, the second approach was used. Fig. 2 (a) presents flow curves of the alumina suspensions (AS) having 50 vol% of solids in the absence and presence of different amounts of processing additives, i.e., CMC and PEI as the thickening and coagulating agents, respectively [28,29]. All suspensions show shear-thinning behaviour where the viscosity decreases with increasing shear rate, indicating the presence of well-stabilized suspensions/inks with required behaviour to go ahead with printing [29,30,44]. The addition of CMC and PEI increases the viscosity of the suspension, highly noticeable when PEI is added, as expected. This behaviour confirms the strong coagulation effect of PEI mentioned in the literature [18,22,29,30,45], which was explained by the interaction of the cationic secondary and tertiary amino groups existing in the PEI with negatively charged functional groups of dispersant adsorbed at alumina particles (Dolapix CE64), neutralizing the charges, and consequently promoting particles connection. This reaction is accompanied by the transformation of the system (aqueous media + alumina particles + dispersant + CMC) from a viscous-like to a solid-like behaviour, i.e., fluid suspensions to pastes/inks. The considered amounts of PEI do not significantly change the flow behaviour of the inks, even if small variances could be observed in the evaluation of viscoelastic properties. Fig. 2(b) presents elastic modulus (G′) and viscous modulus (G″) as a function of the complex shear stress. All inks present higher elastic modulus than the viscous modulus, revealing a gel-like system, as predictable. Independently of the amount of PEI, all the inks stay stable over a wide range of applied shear stress, meaning high linear viscoelastic region (LVR), a good indication that the deposited filaments will be mechanically stable during the printing process with sufficient mechanical strength to support the weight of the next layers [29,30,44]. Furthermore, all inks display elastic modulus in the range of ~106–107 Pa, which are indicative values for printable inks for robocasting. At a certain value of applied shear stress, G″ intersects G′. This is the yield stress point, from which the rupture of the network formed between the polymeric matrix and the Al2O3 ceramic particles occurred, i.e., a gel transition from solid-like to liquid-like behaviour is succeeded. This interception occurs at higher shear stress values as the amount of PEI increases, meaning that stronger gel is formed. According to M'Barki et al. [44], the inks to print dense ceramics should have rheological properties different from those used to produce porous structures. For the dense structures, the cylindrical filaments extruded from the nozzles should flow enough after deposition to fill the gaps between their rod-like shape and to avoid the collapse of the printed part. Having this in mind, 0.2 wt% was the amount of PEI selected to go ahead with printing experiments. 3.2 Structural properties of alumina bars Fig. 3 (a–e) present relative density, percentage of linear shrinkage (from dried to sintered samples), flexural strength, Young's modulus and hardness of the alumina structures printed by robocasting (R) with the three infill orientations (Fig. 1, R-A1, R-A2 and R-A3) inside paraffin (P) and then sintered at 1550 °C during 2 h holding time (R-A1-P-1550, R-A2-P-1550 and R-A3-P-1550). The same properties were evaluated for R-A3 configuration printed in air at room temperature with controlled humidity (R-A3-Air), sintered at both temperatures, 1550 °C and 1600 °C (R-A3-Air-1550 and R-A3-Air-1600), for the same holding time (2 h). For comparison, results for analogous structures (shape and size) obtained by slip casting (SC) from the alumina suspensions containing 50 vol% and sintered at both temperatures (SC-1550 and SC-1600) are also presented. Concerning the samples printed inside paraffin (P) and sintered at 1550 °C/2 h, Fig. 3(a) shows that R-A1-P-1550 and R-A3-P-1550 present similar mean relative densities (≈96.5%), while R-A2-P-1550 presents the lowest average value (≈95%). When the R-A3 configuration structure was printed in air with a controlled humidity rate, keeping the sintering temperature (R-A3-Air-1550), an increase in the mean relative density (≈98%) was noticed. Increasing the sintering temperature to 1600 °C, the mean relative density of this later R-A3 configuration also increases (R-A3-Air-1600), reaching values around 99%. The average relative densities of these samples (R-A3-Air-1550 and R-A3-Air-1600) are comparable with those attained for the slip casting ones (SC-1550 and SC-1600) as reference conventional production process. As shown in Fig. 3(b), average linear shrinkage values in the range of 17–20% are obtained for structures fabricated by robocasting, with negligible changes between different infill orientations and sintering temperatures, while values around 15% are detected for SC samples. The shrinkage differences in robocasting specimens, when compared to SC, could be attributed to the presence of organic components in the printable inks (and dried specimens), which are burned out during sintering, causing higher retraction [32,46,47]. Shrinkage results for slip casting samples are in good agreement with the literature results, for high concentrated alumina suspensions (> 45 vol%) and sintering temperatures in the range of 1550–1600 °C [48]. Besides relative density, flexural strength and Young's modulus (Fig. 3(c,d)) are mechanical properties reliant on the printing strategy (in-fill configuration of filaments) and printing environment (paraffin bath or in air). Regarding hardness (Fig. 3(e)), similar values are obtained for all analysed samples (≈16–17 GPa) as typical for alumina ceramics sintered at 1550–1600 °C [49], without relevant changes between robocasting and SC samples. Hardness values are usually dependent on both density and grain size, and smaller grain size could enhance hardness [50,51].The differences observed in the samples' relative density (Fig. 5a) did not affect significantly the hardness values, since a microindenter was used. Additionally, the small increase of 50 °C in the sintering temperature (from 1550 to 1600 °C) was not expressively changing the grain size (as following presented in Fig. 5) which could explain the similar hardness values attained for all samples sintered at both temperatures. Fig. 3(c,d) show that longitudinal configuration of filaments (R-A3-P-1550) in robocasting alumina samples printed inside paraffin is the printing strategy that results in higher flexural strength and higher Young's modulus, while the transversal one (R-A2-P-1550) is that presenting lower values (all sintered at 1550 °C). Printing in air with controlled humidity (R-A3-Air-1550), instead of paraffin bath (R-A3-P-1550), and increasing sintering temperature to 1600 °C (R-A3-Air-1600) improve both properties, where flexural strength and Young's modulus reach mean values around 340–350 MPa and 350–360 GPa, respectively. These results are also in good agreement with densification results (shown in Fig. 3(a)). Furthermore, for a given printing strategy and condition, flexural strength exhibits high variability among the results obtained for samples fabricated by robocasting (clearer for the samples printed inside paraffin bath), when compared to the traditional colloidal-based SC method. To understand these results, the inner macrostructure of the different printed prismatic models was analysed in the cross-section of the bars cut off in the orthogonal direction to the longitudinal axis (Ox, Fig. 1). Fig. 4 presents the cross-section images for the robocasting structures with different in-fill patterns, printed in paraffin bath or at air and sintered at both 1550 °C and 1600 °C temperatures. Comparing R-A1-P-1550, R-A2-P-1550 and R-A3-P-1550, three different macrostructural features can be observed. The R-A1-P-1550 sample presents a high amount of porosity near the side walls/bounding box perimeter of the bar. Oppositely, in the R-A2-P-1550 structure, macropores were not detected in this cutting direction, being instead highly visible the bonds between the different layers/filaments. Both macrostructural features noted in the above-mentioned ones were not visible in R-A3-P-1550 structure, even though porosity between filaments in the first printed layers was detected. Printing this last patterning in air, the porosity in the first layers disappeared, resulting in a highly homogeneous macrostructure, similar for both sintering temperatures (R-A3-Air-1550 and R-A3-Air-1600). These macrostructural features are shown with higher detail in the SEM images presented in Fig. 5 . For all different samples, the first images correlate well with the observations from Fig. 4. Looking in more detail at the porosity, it is possible to observe two types of pores (shape and size) depending on the in-fill orientation and patterning design used for alumina bars fabrication. As already mentioned, R-A1 printing patterning (constituted by two consecutive layers with printed filaments in two directions, 0 and 90°) results in a mixture of different pore sizes (voids) and shapes, highly visible between the perimeter filament of the bounding box and the contiguous inner region of the bar. Additionally, the poor connection between the filaments printed in different directions from the consecutive layers results in a pore with a triangular shape, due to the patterning formed by the filaments ordered in different directions and their respective rod-like shape. When all layers are printed with filaments in the Ox direction (0°, R-A3-P-1550), the pores presented a rhombus shape, resulting from the void space formed between the 4 rod-like filaments. No porosity is visible in the cross-section of the bars printed with R-A2 configuration (R-A2-P-1550), while if the sample was cut in the Ox printing direction a similar pore shape and size as that observed for the R-A3-P-1550 sample should be evident. Looking at the microstructure inside filaments (picture with high ampliation in Fig. 5) it is highly similar in the R-A1-P-1550, R-A2-P-1550 and R-A3-P-1550, as well as R-A3-Air-1550 samples, as expected. Increasing sintering temperature to 1600 °C (R-A3-Air-1600) the microstructure does not present significative changes in respect to the grain size, although microporosity may be lower according to the densification results (Fig. 3(a)). On the one hand, the low amounts of organic binders used in the paste preparation (CMC and PEI) could explain the absence of high perceptible porosity inside filaments. On the other hand, paraffin could be responsible for some bigger porosity (essentially the one observed in the first printed layers of R-A3-P-1550, Fig. 4), since it might fill some of the gaps between filaments during printing, getting imprisoned inside the green structure and consequently avoiding the filament's paste relaxation after printing to allow filling these voids. As an organic component, it can be burned out during the sintering step using a slower heating schedule, although it was not enough to eliminate high dimensional pores. For comparison purposes, and as expected, the samples obtained by slip casting sintered at 1550 °C and 1600 °C (SC-1550 and SC-1600) present a uniform macrostructure (Fig. 6 (a,c)). The microstructure for both samples (Fig. 6(b,d)) is similar to that observed for the robocasting samples (Fig. 5), both exhibiting small pores inside the grains and grain boundaries, in accordance with relative density values (Fig. 3(a)). Increasing temperature from 1550 °C to 1600 °C the grain growth is not highly perceptible as observed for R-A3-Air-1550 and R-A3-Air-1600 (Fig. 5). 3.3 Numerical evaluation of anisotropy Fig. 7 presents the SOLIDWORKS 2020 geometric approximations of the bars printed by robocasting, according to the different in-fill orientations (R-A1, R-A2 and R-A3). Volume fractions of material resulted in 0.9215 for the longitudinal arrangement (R-A3), 0.9241 for the transversal (R-A2) and 0.9488 for the alternating orthogonal one (R-A1). Two base RUC were extracted from these geometric approximations for simulation, as shown in Fig. 8 . The resulting volume fractions were now 0.9276 for the uniaxial arrangement (R-A2 and R-A3) and 0.9532 for the alternating orthogonal one (R-A1). These values are slightly higher than those presented for R-A1, R-A2 and R-A3 bars (Fig. 7) because of the outer layers of the latter. The analysis of average displacements and reaction loads/stresses provide information to evaluate not only the effective Young's modulus of the materials for the three orthogonal axes (Ox, Oy and Oz) but also to evaluate the Poisson coefficient for the respective planes. These are shown in Table 1 , where E ef is the effective Young's modulus, E fr the base material value scaled down to the volume fraction (theoretical maximum), and ν ij each of the Poisson's ratios. The first take from these values is the fact that these materials are effectively anisotropic. As expected, the stiffness for the unidirectional arrangement along the filament axis (R-A2 and R-A3) is equal to the theoretical maximum for a parallel arrangement (see Eq. (1)). For this RUC, it is also notable that, for the transversal directions, the more compact arrangement along the Oz axis leads to a higher stiffness when compared to the Oy axis. As for the alternating orthogonal arrangement (R-A1), it presents a stiffer behaviour in Oz when compared to the unidirectional due to the material continuity provided by the arrangement (according to Fig. 8). More interesting is the fact that it presents isotropic behaviour in the Oxy plane, which is shown both by Young's modulus and Poisson's coefficient values [52]. Fig. 9 shows the deformed shapes and (normalized) axial stress distributions for the components on the unidirectional (Ox) and bidirectional (Ox and Oy) printing. Isovalues show, as expected, a much more homogeneous response for the filaments aligned with the loading, following a parallel distribution and a stiffer behaviour. For the one-dimensional topology, this direction is much stiffer than the others, where the series arrangement provides a worse response. An intermediate case can be expected for the bidirectional arrangement (R-A1), where a behaviour close to transversally isotropic (tetragonal, in fact) is shown. For both arrangements, the direction orthogonal to the printing plane offers the worse stiffness results. Nevertheless, as shown in Fig. 10 , the filament interaction for the bidirectional arrangement (R-A1) is more three-dimensional, with a more consistent material distribution that provides a more continuous stress distribution and, as previously stated, a stiffer response. Considering the volume fractions of the material obtained from these geometric approximations, a theoretical porosity (assuming no filaments' deformation during printing and sintering processes) was calculated. Fig. 11 presents experimental versus theoretical porosity values for the alumina samples. For all robocasting specimens, the experimental values for porosity are lower than the theoretical ones (in particular for R-A3), as expected from the rheological behaviour of the inks (Fig. 2). After deposition, the ink filament can slightly flow, changing from a perfect cylindrical shape to a more elliptic one and, consequently, filling the void space between filaments and reducing porosity level. Also, R-A3 specimens present a relevant decrease in the experimental porosity when the sintering temperature increases from 1550 °C to 1600 °C. This result was expected, and it is in good agreement with the increased relative density values (Fig. 3) and observed microstructures (Fig. 5) for samples sintered at 1600 °C. Slip casting samples are considered as control bulk material and their relative density is expected to be 100% (i.e., theoretical porosity 0%). However, the existence of small defects (e.g., due to air bubbles in the suspension and/or poor particles' packing behaviour in some parts of the samples) are common in SC procedures [11,53], which could explain the existence of 1–2% of porosity in experimental samples (small pores, Fig. 6) and so, the presence of SC samples in the opposite way to robocasting in Fig. 11. 4 Discussion Printing defects as observed in the present work have been recently mentioned by M. Orlovská et al. [54] in alumina ceramics prepared by Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF). The authors mentioned that voids between filaments appeared for different reasons: (i) solid layers and bounding box of the structure (perimeters) encircle the inner structure, (ii) layer thickness and (iii) weak interfaces between adjacent paths. Although the authors used a different technique, where binder amounts are higher and binder burnout could also be responsible for the formation of defects, the reasons appointed for the macroporosity (porosity between filaments) could fit the results attained in the present work. Robocasting uses negligible amounts of binders when compared to FFF as an advantage to decrease defects, while the rheological behaviour of the ink could be fine-tuned to fill voids between filaments after printing, improving material packing and densification. In fact, the resultant macrostructure as a consequence of the different printing patterns and combination of layer paths has a straight connection with mechanical properties and have been also studied by other authors using other AM technologies and ceramic materials [55,56]. Regarding the variability of results on the flexural strength tests (Fig. 3(c)) for the calculation of effective properties such as stiffness, rendering them less reliable for ceramics – especially with heterogeneous topologies resulting from AM strategies – a numerical evaluation was performed to support this discussion. The modelled samples were simplified, using an adequate level of detail for this analysis. Accurate models have computational requirements that render them unfeasible for meshing and analysis, while not providing better information when compared with the reduced models presented here. Fig. 12 shows the geometries used for these studies, for bending over the Oy axis. Filament diameter and distribution parameters are the same as before, while the envelope dimensions are 1.75 × 17.7 × 1.89 mm3. Despite the same envelope, material volume fractions are different, with 0.89 for the longitudinal (Ox) layout and 0.92 for the transversal (Oy) one. These analyses are also undertaken within the bounds of linear elasticity. In this sense, the absolute levels of stress and the overall response are always proportional to the imposed state and absolute values ignored, taken in comparative form for the sake of the discussion. The isovalues of the von Mises stress distribution are shown in Fig. 12. The transversal arrangement showed a stiffer response than the longitudinal one, with the differences in stiffness much higher than the differences in volume fraction and more pronounced than for the RUC. This means that the influence of material distribution increases with the complexity of the loading and resulting stress states. One of the factors which can be verified is that the average cross-section is higher for the transversal one, a determining factor for the behaviour in bending. It also ends up having more material the farthest from the neutral plane, rendering a stiffer response. At the same time, partly connected to this, it tends to generate higher peak stresses. This is, in fact, the focus of this study. Not in terms of the value itself, albeit over 15% higher, but in the fact that these peaks appear not on the extremes of the cross-section, as shown for the more conventional response of the aligned longitudinal filaments, but as multiple localized peaks within the transitions between transversal filaments. This is compatible with phenomena of stress concentration [57], which, as expected, is shown to be much more critical for the transversal configuration, consistent also with the distributions seen on the RUC. The multiple transitions between filaments, dependant not only on the global topology but also on the local effects, created multiple nucleation places for stress concentration. This is made even more critical for inherently heterogeneous materials as ceramics, with the added impact of printing variability superimposed by heating and densification variability. This is part of the explanation for the variability of results for the experimental tests, especially for specimens with transversal filament deposition, where every small geometric and process deviation leads to stress peaks, which, for such fragile materials, lead to a premature failure. The variation of Young's modulus (for the different alumina samples printed by robocasting) can be analysed with respect to the porosity experimentally obtained and theoretically predicted (calculated in the geometric approximations, Fig. 7). For that, Fig. 13 (a) presents the experimental Young's modulus vs. experimental porosity obtained for the robocasting and SC samples, together with the analytical bound of Voigt and upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman for both sintering temperatures (1550 °C and 1600 °C). As expected, Young's moduli of the robocasting specimens are below the bounds obtained for the corresponding sintering temperatures. However, those of the slip casting specimens slightly surpass the bounds which can be explained by the slight overestimation of the corresponding experimental porosity. On the other hand, Fig. 13(a) also shows that Young's modulus values are close to the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman for the R-A3 specimens sintered at 1600 °C. Regarding the different robocasting specimens, Young's modulus is higher for the R-A3 specimens, which can be explained by the longitudinal nature of the filaments, while for both R-A1 and R-A2 specimens the experimental results are substantially lower, being this characteristic more relevant for the R-A2 specimen than for the R-A1 one. This can be explained by the existence of transversal filaments, which, in the presence of defects (e.g., weak interfilament bonding, air bubbles) leads to a strong degradation of the longitudinal stiffness of the specimens. Fig. 13(b) presents both experimental and numerical results for Young's modulus as a function of porosity, the analytical bound of Voigt and the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman (H-S UB), and the Mooney-type exponential relation (M-T ER) of Pabst-Gregorová for all samples sintered at 1550 °C. Note that the numerical results are obtained by finite element analyses and correspond to the stiffness values in the longitudinal direction of the specimens. Fig. 13(b) shows that the numerical and experimental values for Young's modulus are quite close, although the numerical values of the porosity are greater than those experimental. This difference between numerical and experimental porosity can be largely explained by the densification due to the flow of the material in real specimens. On the other hand, the numerical values for Young's modulus of the robocasting specimens are, as expected, below the corresponding bound of Voigt and the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman. The exception is the R-A3 specimen, whose result is above the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman, corresponding to the value given by the bound of Voigt. Finally, the experimental result for the R-A3 specimens and the numerical result for the R-A1 specimen are in good agreement with the analytical predictions of the Mooney-type exponential relation, being the R-A1 and R-A2 experimental results and the R-A2 numerical results below the analytical predictions. 5 Final remarks and conclusions Robocasting was successfully used to print dense alumina ceramics by fine-tuning the rheological properties of the inks, infill orientation of filaments and environment during the printing process. The CMC and PEI mixture (0.5 wt% and 0.2 wt%) in a 50 vol% solids suspension resulted in a feedstock with proper rheological behaviour during printing and with the ability to flow after deposition to fill the gaps in-between filaments. The in-fill orientation of the filaments influenced the mechanical properties of the sintered parts, namely flexural strength and Young's modulus, with optimal performance observed for specimens with longitudinal filament's printing in all consecutive layers. Printing environment (paraffin bath or air with controlled humidity) and sintering temperature (1550 °C or 1600 °C) also determined relative density and consequently, the mechanical properties. Alumina samples, printed with longitudinal configuration, in air with controlled humidity and sintered at 1600 °C for 2 h exhibited mean relative density around 99%. The values attained for mean flexural strength (≈350 MPa), Young's modulus (≈366 GPa) and hardness (≈17 GPa) were comparable to those obtained for slip casting samples produced with the same sintering conditions. The numerical results presented in this work were used to provide further insight into the anisotropic material behaviour of the printed alumina specimens. The different RUC arrangements showed the influence of the printing strategies on the stiffness of these materials, with values that range from the theoretical maximum obtained for the axial filament alignment to lower values that depend strongly on the printing parameters. Furthermore, bending tests with different orientation showed that, while in accordance with the microscale analysis, the overall response of printed parts is much more dependent on the material configuration as a whole and (macro)scale effects. Moreover, critical for ceramic materials, stress concentration proved to be a factor that might lead to a dispersion of results on experimental tests. Finally, the experimental results for Young's modulus were compared with the bound of Voigt-Reuss and the upper bound of Hashin-Shtrikman, as well as with the analytical predictions of a Mooney-type exponential relation, and were shown to be generally in accordance with the observed experimental facts. doc_title: Association between respiratory hospital admissions and air quality in Portugal: A count time series approach
doc_abstract: Copyright: © 2021 Martins et al. This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original author and source are credited.Although regulatory improvements for air quality in the European Union have been made, air pollution is still a pressing problem and, its impact on health, both mortality and morbidity, is a topic of intense research nowadays. The main goal of this work is to assess the impact of the exposure to air pollutants on the number of daily hospital admissions due to respiratory causes in 58 spatial locations of Portugal mainland, during the period 2005-2017. To this end, INteger Generalised AutoRegressive Conditional Heteroskedastic (INGARCH)based models are extensively used. This family of models has proven to be very useful in the analysis of serially dependent count data. Such models include information on the past history of the time series, as well as the effect of external covariates. In particular, daily hospitalisation counts, air quality and temperature data are endowed within INGARCH models of optimal orders, where the automatic inclusion of the most significant covariates is carried out through a new block-forward procedure. The INGARCH approach is adequate to model the outcome variable (respiratory hospital admissions) and the covariates, which advocates for the use of count time series approaches in this setting. Results show that the past history of the count process carries very relevant information and that temperature is the most determinant covariate, among the analysed, for daily hospital respiratory admissions. It is important to stress that, despite the small variability explained by air quality, all models include on average, approximately two air pollutants covariates besides temperature. Further analysis shows that the one-step-ahead forecasts distributions are well separated into two clusters: one cluster includes locations exclusively in the Lisbon area (exhibiting higher number of one-step-ahead hospital admissions forecasts), while the other contains the remaining locations. This results highlights that special attention must be given to air quality in Lisbon metropolitan area in order to decrease the number of hospital admissions.

doc_title: Advantages of porcine xenograft over autograft in sinus lift: A randomised clinical trial
doc_abstract: © 2021 by the authors. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.This study aimed to compare the performance of intra-oral autologous bone grafts versus porcine xenografts in a two-step lateral window sinus lift. This split-mouth randomised controlled trial sequentially enrolled 12 patients with a 6-month follow-up. For each patient, a simultaneous randomised bilateral maxillary sinus lift was performed and filled with autologous bone from the mandible (control) or a porcine xenograft (test). A bone biopsy sample was collected during the implant placement for histological and histomorphometric analysis. CT scans were performed at the beginning and at the end of the trial to assess radiological evolution. A comparison of initial and six-month CT scans indicated statistically significant increases in bone level for both materials (7.8 ± 2.4 mm for autologous and 8.7 ± 2.2 mm for xenograft, p < 0.05), and there were no significant differences between the performance of the two materials over time (p = 0.26). The histological analysis showed various stages of the remodelling process and no cells or other signs of inflammation or infection were visible in both groups. The porcine xenografts presented similar results for the studied variables when compared to autologous bone, being a reasonable alternative for a sinus lift.

doc_title: The role of the atmospheric aerosol in weather forecasts for the Iberian Peninsula: Investigating the direct effects using the WRF-Chem model
doc_abstract: © 2021 by the authors. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.In the atmosphere, aerosols play an important role in climate change, the Earth’s environment and human health. The purpose of this study is to investigate the direct and semi-direct aerosol effects on weather forecasting, focusing on the Iberian Peninsula (IP). To that end, two Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF)-Chem simulations (with and without aerosol feedback) for an entire year (2015) were performed. The model setup includes two nested domains run in two-way mode, allowing the downscaling for the IP domain at a 5 × 5 km2 high-horizontal resolution. The results were explored through agreement of pairs of time series and their spatial variability in order to analyse the importance of including the online-coupled aerosol radiative effect on the meteorological variables: Shortwave (solar) radiation, air temperature and precipitation. Significant variations of agreement were found when capturing both temporal and spatial patterns of the analysed meteorological variables. While the spatial distribution of temperature and precipitation is similar throughout the IP domain, with agreement values ranging from 0.87 up to 1.00, the solar radiation presents a distinct spatial pattern with lower agreement values (0.68–0.75) over ocean and higher agreement (0.75–0.98) over land regions. With regard to the spatial differences between simulations, the aerosol contributed to a considerable decrease in annual mean and maximum radiation (up to 20 and 40Wm-2, respectively), slightly impacting the temperature variation (up to 0.5°C). These results suggest that the aerosol feedback effects should be accounted when performing weather forecasts, and not only for purposes of air quality assessment.

doc_title: Lateral window technique: A focus review
doc_abstract: © 2021 The British Association of Oral Surgeons and John Wiley & Sons LtdThe posterior alveolar bone region of the maxilla has, in more than 40% of the cases, a height inferior to 4 mm, thus making rehabilitation with implants a clinical challenge. This focus literature review was carried out through an exhaustive literature search in PubMed, ScienceDirect, LILACS, Web of Science, Scielo and Cochrane Library. The aim was to illustrate and analyse various factors that should be accounted for while applying the maxillary sinus elevation technique. The lateral osteotomy technique is carefully described including its indications, complications, contraindications, as well as, different factors to take into account, such as the use of electric piezo, graft materials, membranes and the expected success rates.

doc_title: On the extremes of the max-INAR(1) process for time series of counts
doc_abstract: © 2021 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.In this paper we investigate extremal properties connected with the so-called max-INAR process of order one based on the binomial thinning operator, and marginal distribution exhibiting regularly-varying right-tail. In particular, attention is paid to the limiting distribution of the number of exceedances of high levels and the joint limiting law of the maximum and the minimum. Furthermore, we also look at the extremal behavior of the max-INAR process of order one under the assumption that its corresponding thinning parameter is random. Finally, the periodic case is also addressed.

doc_title: Propofol TCI Reductions Do Not Attenuate Significant Falls in Cardiac Output Associated with Anesthesia Induction and Knee-Chest Positioning in Spinal Surgery
doc_abstract: © 2019 Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. All rights reserved.Background:Induction of anesthesia and the knee-chest position are associated with hemodynamic changes that may impact patient outcomes. The aim of this study was to assess whether planned reductions in target-controlled infusion propofol concentrations attenuate the hemodynamic changes associated with anesthesia induction and knee-chest position.Materilas and Methods:A total of 20 patients scheduled for elective lumbar spinal surgery in the knee-chest position were included. In addition to standard anesthesia monitoring, bispectral index and noninvasive cardiac output (CO) monitoring were undertaken. The study was carried out in 2 parts. In phase 1, target-controlled infusion propofol anesthesia was adjusted to maintain BIS 40 to 60. In phase 2, there were 2 planned reductions in propofol target concentration: (1) immediately after loss of consciousness - reduction calculated using a predefined formula, and (2) before positioning - reduction equal to the average percentage decrease in CO after knee-chest position in phase 1. Changes from baseline in CO and other hemodynamic variables following induction of anesthesia and knee-chest positioning were compared.Results:Induction of anesthesia led to decreases of 25.6% and 19.8% in CO from baseline in phases 1 and 2, respectively (P<0.01). Knee-chest positioning resulted in a further decrease such that the total in CO reduction from baseline to 10 minutes after positioning was 38.4% and 46.9% in phases 1 and 2, respectively (P<0.01). There was no difference in CO changes between phases 1 and 2, despite the planned reductions in propofol during phase 2. There was no significant correlation between changes in CO and mean arterial pressure.Conclusions:Planned reductions in propofol concentration do not attenuate anesthesia induction and knee-chest position-related decreases in CO. The knee-chest position is an independent risk factor for decrease in CO. Minimally invasive CO monitors may aid in the detection of clinically relevant hemodynamic changes and guide management in anesthetized patients in the knee-chest position.

doc_title: Euro-Cordex Regional Projection Models: What Kind of Agreement for Europe?
doc_abstract: © 2019, International Association for Mathematical Geosciences.EURO-CORDEX is an international initiative which provides regional climate projections based on multiple dynamical and empirical–statistical downscaling models. The goal of this work is to analyse the agreement between projections of the CLMCOM-CCLM4-8-17 (CLMCOM) and SMHI-RCA4 (SMHI) models across Europe. The variables temperature, precipitation and solar radiation were considered for a historical period (1971–2005) and for a future scenario (2006–2040). The overall agreement (A) is defined as the normalised area of the magnitude-squared coherence function over the frequency range (averaged over time), being 0 for no agreement and 1 for total agreement between models. The relative mean difference (M) and difference between the coefficients of variation (V) are also explored, since coherence analysis cannot evaluate differences in mean and variability. Agreement values ranging from 0.32 to 0.74, 0.28 to 0.69 and 0.32 to 0.58 were found for temperature, precipitation and solar radiation, respectively, for the historical period. In all cases, the results show better agreement for lower than higher frequencies. Overall, the time series from both models behave fairly similarly for lower frequencies (i.e. the trend of the time series), while for higher frequencies (i.e. rapid changes in the time series), the similarities between the models are less consistent. For temperature, the M and V values are smaller than 2.5%, while for precipitation and solar radiation they can exceed 50% and 35%, respectively. Further analysis revealed that the contribution of winter and summer differs considerably for M and V values. In conclusion, it seems that such models can provide fairly similar results when considering long periods of time.

doc_title: Sex estimation using the mandibular canine index components
doc_abstract: © 2018, Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.The mandibular canine index (MCI) has been described as a suitable methodology for sex estimation in forensic scenarios but there are contradictory reports about its accuracy. Moreover, the two mandibular canine teeth must be available, which is not always a viable option. The aim of this study was to strip the MCI by analyzing the MCI itself and its components, in order to optimize its use for sex estimation. The mesiodistal dimensions of the mandibular canine crown and the mandibular canine arch width were measured in a sample of 120 cast models. Five predictor variables were considered in this study: the standard MCI, a variation of the MCI using the left canine, and MCI components (MD43, MD33 and D33–43). Multivariate binary logistic regression was performed using stepwise forward approach to select the most statistical relevant variables on the probability of a cast being from a female. The estimated probability was then analyzed with respect to performance in sex classification (ROC analysis and optimal cut-offs accuracy) and compared with the performance of the univariate variables. MCI43 and MCI33 presented the lowest performance (64.2% and 63.3% respectively), and the highest overall accuracy was attained using the MD43 and MD33 (85.8% in both cases). The multivariate logistic model obtained (using MD43 and MD33) exhibited the same accuracy as the logistic model based solely on MD43 (85.8%). Our results suggest that MD43 should be used instead of MCI for sex estimation.

doc_title: On the parameters estimation of hiv dynamic models
doc_abstract: © 2019, National Statistical Institute. All rights reserved.This work proposes an estimation method to obtain the optimal parameter estimates of a mathematical model, from a set of CD4+T values collected in a HIV patient. To this end, the following scheme is adopted: The first step consists in selecting an initial estimate for the model's parameters as that having minimum square error, from a set of uniform randomly generated candidates. In the second step, the initial solution is refined by an optimization algorithm with constraints and bounds (imposed by physiology), resulting on the optimal estimate. The proposed method is validated through a simulation study and illustrated with an application to a real data set of CD4+T cells counts for several HIV patients.

doc_title: Effect of hemodynamic changes in plasma propofol concentrations associated with knee-chest position in spinal surgery: A prospective study
doc_abstract: © 2019, Author(s).Background: Anesthesia induction and maintenance with propofol can be guided by target-controlled infusion (TCI) systems using pharmacokinetic (Pk) models. Physiological variables, such as changes in cardiac output (CO), can influence propofol pharmacokinetics. Knee-chest (KC) surgical positioning can result in CO changes. Objectives: This study aimed to evaluate the relationship between propofol plasma concentration prediction and CO changes after induction and KC positioning. Methods: This two-phase prospective cohort study included 20 patients scheduled for spinal surgery. Two different TCI anesthesia protocols were administered after induction. In phase I (n = 9), the loss of consciousness (LOC) concentration was set as the propofol target concentration and CO changes following induction and KC positioning were quantified. In phase II (n = 11), based on data from phase I, two reductions in the propofol target concentration on the pump were applied after LOC and before KC positioning. Propofol plasma concentrations were measured at different moments in both phases: after induction and after KC positioning. Results: Schnider Pk model showed a good performance in predicting propofol concentration after induction; however, after KC positioning, when a significant drop in CO occurred, the measured propofol concentrations were markedly underestimated. Intended reductions in the propofol target concentration did not attenuate HD changes. In the KC position, there was no correlation between the propofol concentration estimated by the Pk model and the measured concentration in plasma, as the latter was much higher (P = 0.013) while CO and BIS decreased significantly (P < 0.001 and P = 0.004, respectively). Conclusions: Our study showed that the measured propofol plasma concentrations during the KC position were significantly underestimated by the Schnider Pk model and were associated with significant CO decrease. When placing patients in the KC position, anesthesiologists must be aware of pharmacokinetic changes and, in addition to standard monitoring, the use of depth of anesthesia and cardiac output monitors may be considered in high-risk patients.

doc_title: Simulation study of HIV temporal patterns using Bayesian methodology
doc_abstract: © 2019, Springer Nature Switzerland AG.Viral load values and CD4+T cells count are markers currently evaluated in the clinical follow-up of HIV/AIDS patients. In this context, it is relevant to develop methods that provide a more complete temporal description of these markers, e.g. in between clinical appointments. To this end, we combine a mathematical model and a Bayesian methodology to estimate trajectories from a set of observed values. Also, we construct a variation band containing the most central trajectories for one patient, by exploring the range of values in the a posteriori distributions. The methods are illustrated with simulated data.

doc_title: Impact of pH on the high-pressure inactivation of microbial transglutaminase
doc_abstract: © 2018 Elsevier LtdMicrobial transglutaminase (MTG) is an enzyme largely used in the food industry, mainly to improve food texture. However, many globular proteins show low susceptibility to the action of this enzyme. High-pressure processing (HPP), being able to change protein conformation, may be a useful tool to increase the accessibility of globular proteins to the action of MTG. Nevertheless, HPP conditions need to be carefully optimized to avoid the expected decrease of enzymatic activity observed above certain conditions of pressure (P), treatment time (t) or temperature (T). Pressure inactivation of MTG under different HPP conditions (200–600 MPa; 20–40 °C; 10–30 min) was evaluated employing a face-centered composite design at four different pH values (4–7). The regression models obtained presented high coefficients of determination and high F values, although they could not explain some of the associated variability. At all the pH values tested, the three main factors (P, T, and t) significantly (p < 0.05) affected the activity of MTG. At least 20% of MTG was inactivated when low pressures (200 MPa) were used at pH 4 and 5, whereas a higher pressure above 400 MPa was needed to obtain a similar inactivation at pH 6 or 7. MTG pressure-inactivation followed first-order kinetics under all tested conditions. Inactivation rate constants decreased with increasing pressure at constant temperature and pH 4, with a positive activation volume (Va), while the opposite was verified for the other pH values. Both activation energy (Ea) and Va were dependent on pH, however, at the lower pH values, Ea and Va did not vary significantly with pressure and temperature, respectively. Overall, MTG can be considered relatively resistant to pressure, particularly near its optimal pH.
